story:
Summary

Toni Morrison's Beloved is one of the most powerful novels of the 20th century. Set in Ohio after the Civil War, the novel tells the story of Sethe and how the legacy of slavery impacts her life after the institution is abolished.

Thurston High's English Department wants to give their 11th grade American Literature students access to this great work and to more works that illustrate and explore the diverse history of our country.

What We Need 

A single copy of Beloved is $18.03

We need 40 copies to begin integrating the book into Ms. Comerford's curriculum

$100 will provide 5 books
$200 will provide 10 books
$400 will provide books for half the class


Every dollar counts!

 

The Impact

Every student gets a book

Every student gets to read Beloved

Ms. Comerford will integrate the book into her curriculum, and your contribution will be lasting for future classes to come

Please comment and tell us your favorite piece of literature!

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Share this link with your family and friends on Facebook and through email
  • Used copies of Beloved can be sent to: Caroline Comerford Thurston High School 333 58th St. Springfield, OR 97478

story:
As a health and education non-profit we've helped hundreds of thousands of women and their families live better and healthier lives with bright ideas since 2000. Now we're poised to help cities help thousands of homeless children and their families with our project, Habitat for Families.  

THE CONCEPT

To install a specialized form of tiny modular houses in a ‘big box’ style warehouse (think Costco) that would give each family a secure place to sleep, read, laugh, do homework and bathe - privately and securely. Set up as a complete working community with resources for families with school children, everyone works or contributes in some way to the habitat. The focus is on families, their children's education and their parent’s advancement back into society.

THE PROJECT

To create a complete packaged, blueprinted and road mapped solution for cities, groups and investors to build and grow micro-community habitats in their cities. 

THE ISSUE

There are over 1.6 million homeless children in our nation. Not winos, drug addicts or cardboard wielding panhandlers, they are children and they are a part of our nation’s future.

Most of our homeless children are victims of the economy and housing meltdown. Surrounded by winos, criminals and drug addicts in mixed use cot shelters, many homeless families choose to take their chances in parks, abandoned houses and cars instead.

THE INSPIRATION

Frustrated by the impossible lives the 11,000 homeless kids are living in my own city, my teen daughter poignantly asked if there really were no smart adults who could solve this problem. 

Inspiration came to her one day in the form of a pink playhouse at Costco and grew from there. 

A well designed incubator warehouse could eliminate neighborhood restrictions that prevent adequate housing.  A success driven community environment within addresses the issues that caused homelessness to begin with.

JOIN US: 

 Tonight when you go to bed remember 1.6 million U.S. children needed solutions today.

PLEASE BE GENEROUS

Together we're the smart adults our children need.

THE PLANS

THE COMMUNITY

Simple modular living quarters with bunks, a writing desk and personal storage is where families can safely and securely bed down with their children at night line the ‘streets’ inside the warehouse. Nice portable showers and lavatories, including handicapped accessible, are plugged into the back of the units for ease of maintenance and sanitation. Blue streets designated on the warehouse floor plan above provide service access. 

Rubber sidewalks and soft synthetic grass define the front yards. Bicycling around the neighborhood makes it the perfect place to be a kid. Holidays and celebrations have a place and meaning once again. 

A community kitchen and dining facility keeps food prep (a fire and vector hazard) out of the dwellings and provides space for meals, interaction and community involvement. Teaching families about cooking and healthy food choices is an important part of community education. 

The habitat houses educational and vocational resources for both students and parents. Well lit study halls, a library and computer lab creates a supportive study area for students to excel in school. 

The centers promote a safe environment and the ability to gain new life skills. Being an active and valued community member teaches children they matter, builds self-esteem and promotes better self-care as well as social skills that will last a lifetime.

PERKS: AS GOOD AS IT GIVES

Our mommas taught us to share as well as help others. Our perks are different in a good way. No one needs another t-shirt or coffee cup. As a non-profit we like to do good with our good, and your good, too. In fact we'll eke as much good out of your good as we possibly can. 

BASIC GOOD FOR EVERYBODY  All contributions make a difference. 

DOING GOOD We’re a 501(c)(3) non-profit, so right off the bat, your donation is tax deductible. We say YAY!

HELLO? it is me you’re looking for? We’ll keep you updated with what’s going on with our project via our Facebook project page @ Habitat for Families.

SAY MY NAME You laid your name down in the street so a child didn't have to. Contributors can choose to be named on our Facebook project page. Otherwise we'll strictly follow our Donor Privacy Policy and keep your information private. 

CHECK OUT OUR PERKS  All of our perks involve paying it forward in your name to one of our listed charities or good cause recipients of your choice. If you have a non-political/non-conflict verified charity you'd rather we contribute to on your behalf, let us know. 

We've selected six charities & causes for the good they do and how they align with our own cause - helping people live better lives. They're mentioned in our perks and all are listed at the end of our campaign. 

Beyond the three basic perks, which everyone receives, our perks don't build upon one another, but each one extends your good to others, on average, by 12.5%. 

HOW WE'LL USE THE FUNDS

While the complete scope of our project will be several hundred thousand dollars, we're starting with $7500 to lay the groundwork. 

 

We’re raising funds in increments to meet our immediate needs and keep the project on track, moving forward in milestones as well as fiscal responsibility. 

We’ll continue working until we have a sustainable solution in every aspect for cities across the nation. 

THE BENEFITS

From construction design to community empowerment and family management, the habitat embodies every facet of providing a safe, meaningful and fiscally complete solution for cities to help this underserved demographic reclaim their lives.

THE IMPACT

 According to the 2009 figures, homeless individual without supportive housing costs the public upwards of $3000 a month, and this doesn't include the life-long effects and costs on children forced to live under such circumstances. The typical public cost for residents in supportive housing, however, is approximately $600 a month.  

   Graph and info via Where We Sleep 

Public costs go down when individuals are no longer homeless. Stopping homelessness, not just through housing, but through better family education and support for our youths and their parents can only further reduce the short and long term societal costs.  Plus it's just the right thing to do. America should not have a single child sleeping in the streets. 

While the cost for a city to build these centers will be dependent on how they address the different facets, initial building costs spread over the number of people served over time should make it an attractive option. Factoring in the social education opportunity, the ability to employ the resident workforce as well as generate goods, services and energy can make this a very smart, cost effective option. 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

We are looking for professionals, experts, mentors and collaborators 

WHAT IF WE DON'T REACH OUR GOAL? 

If we can't raise a mere $7500 to begin to improve the lives of 1.6 million U.S. children, then shame on us as a society. Please contribute. You matter and your contribution matters. 

However, If we don't reach our goal, we'll take the funds we do receive and continue to find ways to reach the professionals we need to connect with to get the job done. If at any point we reach a deal breaking double jeopardy form of Murphy's Law, involving un-variance-able building codes, ridiculous government bureaucracy, an act of God, or a pandemic chocolate shortage, we'll use the funds to continue our daily non-profit work of helping women and their families all over the world live better, healthier lives. But don't expect us to give up all that easily.

MEET US!  We're the team leading this project for our organization

ABOUT THE DRAWINGS 

Annette has lifelong construction experience and an interior design (UCLA) background, so she drew the simple plans. In the PDF you can zoom in further explore the basic idea of the community. The dining and multi-purpose rooms are not correctly sized or placed. Those have to be determined by how they will be used and how many will use them at a time. The houses are drawn to scale and basic code, however, we need professional help with egress, safety and fire codes. The reason we are raising funds is to get to the bottom of all these aspects, develop a solid plan and go from there. Every great thing starts out as a great idea and builds from there. 

ABOUT OUR PERK PARTNERS

IntelliWheels  A campaign colleague, they are very good cause working to greatly improve wheelchair wheels through the use of gears. Awesome cause! 

Habitat for Humanity Believes that every man, woman and child should have a decent, safe and affordable place to live. We could not agree more.

Kiva  As micro-lending organization, we'll keep re-investing your dollars over and over again.

Make a Wish Foundation  Grants the wish of a child diagnosed with a life-threatening medical condition. 

Alex’s Lemonade Stand Foundation  Raises money for childhood cancer, but also empowers other children to make a difference for children with cancer. 

Center for Neighborhood Enterprise  Transforms lives, schools and troubled neighborhoods from the inside out.


GET INVOLVED. GET YOUR KIDS INVOLVED.

Are you still here? Wow. That's dedication. Please join us. Lay your name down by contributing in any number of ways and help get our communities children off the streets. 

How many homeless children live in your city? Find out! Have your kids find out. Post the city and numbers in our comments or on our Facebook Project page. We'll create a graphic with your first name and the number of homeless children in your city and add it to our campaign gallery and Facebook Project page. 


“Never doubt that a small group of thoughtful, committed citizens can change the world; indeed, it's the only thing that ever has.” -- Margaret Mead


THANKS AND GRATITUDE

...more is coming! 

Photography 

Beth Saltus Kalosky http://bnkphotography.com


       Habitat for Families drawings, concepts and materials Copyright © 2013

story:
Help Buy Writing Manuals for Inmate College Students

I teach a section of Religion 102 at Garden State Youth Correctional Facility, through the Princeton Prison Teaching Initiative. We are at (or over) our budget for course materials, but my 10 students really need copies of Kate Turabian's Manual for Writers of Research Papers, Theses, and Dissertations. They struggle with issues such as organizing their papers, attributing sources properly, and formatting citations correctly. We could just give them some handouts, but if they have Turabian, they can use it to continue working on their research and writing skills in future courses and after they are released. In addition, they can start building their personal libraries of essential reference materials for college-level work.

What We Need

  • I have 10 students, and I can get brand-new copies at a discount through a local independent bookstore. So, really, $180 would cover all ten copies of Turabian plus the indiegogo fees (12%).
  • If I raise $500, the indiegogo fees will be lower (7%), and I will use the additional funds to purchase similar reference materials for students in other classes and/or source materials for my students' research papers. You will have my undying gratitude.
  • Many of our students continue their education after they are released from prison. They will continue to use the Turabian manual for years.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you live in or near New Jersey and are interested in teaching or tutoring, please let me know. Right now we have an especially urgent need for a Chinese-and/or Korean-speaking tutor for one of our students.
  • If this project is successful, I'm thinking of running a larger book drive for inmate college students in the spring. Princeton's Prison Teaching Initiative offers courses in math, sociology, English, religion and other fields at both Garden State and Albert C. Wagner Youth Correctional Facility. In addition, our initiative is part of a larger statewide consortium that offers for-credit college courses to inmates in institutions all over New Jersey. All of our inmate students need more resources. Please keep me and my students in your thoughts and/or prayers, and watch for information about ways to help in the future.

story:
Balefire is an organization that is focused on reducing the scope of drug and alcohol abuse in the United States.  Balefire believes that our youth are bombarded by a negative message that abusing drugs and alcohol promotes fun without consequences.

Balefire has begun a campaign of education and awareness by college students that will target their college peers and even younger students.  Working with a local television station (WACH), Balefire will create a minimum of two PSAs from one fraternity (Sigma Alpha Epsilon) and one sorority (Zeta Tau Alpha) from the University of South Carolina.  They will work in a competition to create the best commercial with the best message.  The students will design the content and the TV station with produce and edit the commercial.

The PSAs will then go onto a website for a period of time to allow for voting.  The winning commercial will be a featured story on the evening news here in Columbia, South Carolina and the PSA will go into rotation for a period of time. 

The most exciting part of this campaign is the promotion of the voting.  In order to vote a person must view all of the PSAs.  We will want to get all of the colleges, high schools and middle schools to view and vote.  This will allow a younger audience to hear a positive message from college students.

We need to raise $4000.00 to allow for two commercials.  If we raise more than our targeted goal we can allow more PSAs to compete from other local colleges.

Our Perks:

 

$1: Credits on our website for being a hero!

 

$5: 3” Balefire sticker for a surface in need of décor!

 

$25: Aluminum 20oz. Bike Water Bottle with Balefire logo

 

$50: A black adjustable hat with three point of embroidery: Front- Balefire logo, Left side- Balefire lettering, Back- flame

 

$75: Two Tone Black and Tan tote with Balefire logo on the sides.

 

$100: The tote, water bottle, sticker and credit on our website.

 

$2000: Opening credits on a single commercial.  With this donation you will have sponsored one full commercial and we will thank you with glorious lettering at the opening of a PSA!

 

Can’t afford to make a donation? That’s ok. Please share our video on your webpage, Facebook or via email. Help us get the word out!

story:
About CardTracker:

Card Tracker is used by players of the Magic the Gathering and Yugi-oh card games.

It allows the players to play several variations of these very popular battle card games.

This app keep track of “health” and “poison” counters so the players don’t have to write them down.

The app also keeps track of scoring history so the players can see how the rounds have progressed.

The app also features a 3D, six-sided dice and a 3D coin so the players can always have a coin flip or dice anytime.

The app can be paused in the event of an in-coming phone call, etc.

It is the best of the best in the iTunes store in this genre.

This app has been released for iPhone, iPad and Android.

Our Mission

nonPareil Institute is dedicated to providing technical training, employment and housing to individuals who have been diagnosed with autism spectrum disorder. We hope to one day be partially self-sustaining from the products our Crew build and market.

 

Our Vision

We envision ever-expanding programs beyond our current technology focus, and expanding our campus model around the world, which will allow a lifetime of sustainability, fulfillment and purpose for adults affected with autism spectrum disorder.

 

Our History

Dan Selec had been thinking about his son's future for a long time. Having a child on the autism spectrum, he asked the same question so many parents ask; "What happens when my son grows up? What is out there that can help him today, in a practical and predictable way?" Dan recognized the interest, ability and passion many like his son seemed to display, especially in regard to PC’s and game consoles. If this passion could be harnessed in the form of technical ability, an entirely new method of communication, expression and productivity would be possible.
The culmination of Dan's thoughts resulted in the foundational nonPareil whitepaper, Technical Training for the Autistic Mind written in July 2008.

Shortly after, Dan met Gary Moore, a parent asking the same questions. Gary is also the parent of a child on the spectrum, and understood the challenges ahead, and also recognized his son’s similar interest in computers and video games. It was at this first meeting that Gary committed to helping Dan take his vision and make it a reality, and in September 2008, they founded Nonpareil Institute.

Dan began training the first student in his kitchen in July 2009, then added a second and third quickly thereafter, due in no small part to the efforts of J’Lynn Anderson who conducted the early student recruiting efforts. The nightly training in Dan’s kitchen quickly grew to 8 students and five nights a week, for over a year. As his wife says today, “It was just our new norm…”
Gary’s efforts during this time were largely directed at building a network of supporters, partners and donors to help fund the young, fledgling company, as well as finding a location for nonPareils’ first training center. Through a mutual friend, an introduction was made to the Executive Director of the Guildhall at SMU-in-Plano, which led to a meeting with the Campus Director to consider space for nonPareil.

The culmination of the efforts of this team resulted in the opening of the first full-time nonPareil operation on the campus of SMU-in-Plano in September 2010. This site, which opened with 8 students, quickly grew to 52 students in the first 8 months. One year later more space was acquired, and the program grew to over 80 students.

Today, 3 of our original students are full-time employees of the company, with 9 other students being part-time staff.
As of June 2012, we have 3 apps in the iTunes store, and 1 in the Android store, as well as many free to play maps and campaigns for various popular games. Students have moved from around the country to enroll in this leading edge, ground-breaking, practical solution for adults with autism spectrum disorder which includes technical training, work, and eventually, a residential campus. 

What Else Can You Do to Help?


Just spread the word about nonPareil and our CardTracker app!
story_txt:
About CardTracker:
Card Tracker is used by players of the Magic the Gathering and Yugi-oh card games.
It allows the players to play several variations of these very popular battle card games.
This app keep track of “health” and “poison” counters so the players don’t have to write them down.
The app also keeps track of scoring history so the players can see how the rounds have progressed.
The app also features a 3D, six-sided dice and a 3D coin so the players can always have a coin flip or dice anytime.
The app can be paused in the event of an in-coming phone call, etc.
It is the best of the best in the iTunes store in this genre.
This app has been released for iPhone, iPad and Android.
Our Mission
nonPareil Institute is dedicated to providing technical training, employment and housing to individuals who have been diagnosed with autism spectrum disorder. We hope to one day be partially self-sustaining from the products our Crew build and market.
 
Our Vision
We envision ever-expanding programs beyond our current technology focus, and expanding our campus model around the world, which will allow a lifetime of sustainability, fulfillment and purpose for adults affected with autism spectrum disorder.
 
Our History
Dan Selec had been thinking about his son's future for a long time. Having a child on the autism spectrum, he asked the same question so many parents ask; "What happens when my son grows up? What is out there that can help him today, in a practical and predictable way?" Dan recognized the interest, ability and passion many like his son seemed to display, especially in regard to PC’s and game consoles. If this passion could be harnessed in the form of technical ability, an entirely new method of communication, expression and productivity would be possible. The culmination of Dan's thoughts resulted in the foundational nonPareil whitepaper, Technical Training for the Autistic Mind written in July 2008. Shortly after, Dan met Gary Moore, a parent asking the same questions. Gary is also the parent of a child on the spectrum, and understood the challenges ahead, and also recognized his son’s similar interest in computers and video games. It was at this first meeting that Gary committed to helping Dan take his vision and make it a reality, and in September 2008, they founded Nonpareil Institute. Dan began training the first student in his kitchen in July 2009, then added a second and third quickly thereafter, due in no small part to the efforts of J’Lynn Anderson who conducted the early student recruiting efforts. The nightly training in Dan’s kitchen quickly grew to 8 students and five nights a week, for over a year. As his wife says today, “It was just our new norm…” Gary’s efforts during this time were largely directed at building a network of supporters, partners and donors to help fund the young, fledgling company, as well as finding a location for nonPareils’ first training center. Through a mutual friend, an introduction was made to the Executive Director of the Guildhall at SMU-in-Plano, which led to a meeting with the Campus Director to consider space for nonPareil. The culmination of the efforts of this team resulted in the opening of the first full-time nonPareil operation on the campus of SMU-in-Plano in September 2010. This site, which opened with 8 students, quickly grew to 52 students in the first 8 months. One year later more space was acquired, and the program grew to over 80 students. Today, 3 of our original students are full-time employees of the company, with 9 other students being part-time staff. As of June 2012, we have 3 apps in the iTunes store, and 1 in the Android store, as well as many free to play maps and campaigns for various popular games. Students have moved from around the country to enroll in this leading edge, ground-breaking, practical solution for adults with autism spectrum disorder which includes technical training, work, and eventually, a residential campus. 
What Else Can You Do to Help?
Just spread the word about nonPareil and our CardTracker app!

story:
Peace! My Name is Daniel, I live in Fort Wayne Indiana. I was born in 1977, when I begin feeling the impact of music that I listened to was right around 1985, The Fat Boys, Run DMC, and the Beastie Boys were the business for the kids in my area. Since then Hip Hop has been a part of my life, Rakim, KRS-One and Public Enemy taught me about a culture I may have never seen had it not been for that awareness that they shared with me through music. I put together a concept a few years ago of getting involved with an already well established Hip Hop scene and trying to bring more underground out of town acts to come and preform. I started a page on Facebook called Fort Wayne Hip Hop Society and began reaching out to others that seemed to share the same ideas as I had and people that were already bringing their elements to the people.

Pillars in the Park is going to be a free all ages show in Friemann Square that showcases the importance of the Pillars of Hip Hop, DJing, B Boying Emceeing, and Graf artists. Building the strength of these elements together with Knowledge is a powerful tool for cultural awareness and bringing the community together to build together and make connections to each other. Music and the other artistic elements of Hip Hop culture can be a positive tool to use for education and and encourage bridge building between people and gives the youth a positive channel for them to be involved in their community and their own creativity. 

So now you may be asking yourself where your donation be going? I have the answer for you. Fort Wayne Hip Hop Society is solely funded by me, I do this out of love, I am the only financier on this project because I want it to remain non-commerical and independant. I have asked for $1500.00 exactly. This would allow me to focus on getting the event organized well without allowing funding to distract from the event. 

Your donations would help to cover rental fees for the Park, Portable Restrooms for the people at the event, trash removal, advertising and promotions, City permits, hospitality for the the artists and preformers.

Since this event is for the people, I thought it would be a good thing for people that support Hip Hop and our local music scene to have a chance to help out and get involved by showing that they want to be a part of this.

If we cannot reach the goal of $1500.00, the funds raised will still be a great help to making this event be the absolute best it can be. If you would like to donate that is great! If you would like to just come out and enjoy the day with us that is great too. 

What is the impact of this event? Will your donation make a difference? Absolutly! Each positive action we make in our community resonates far beyond the single act. It changes all who connect with it. For you to donate or simply get the word out about this campaign and the event is a step in connecting people and making something good happen in the world.

We hope to see you July 28th in Frieman Square in Fort Wayne for Pillars in the Park!

"There aint no Nation like a Donation, No City like Generosity."

story:
My Father put his car in storage when I was born. He planned on taking it back out a few years later when I was out of a car seat. Then when my mom's cystic fibrosis got so bad she needed a lung transplant, the car was forgotten. My mom died about six months after the transplant; which I'm grateful for those six months though I wish it was more. My dad was widowed at 26, and chose to raise me over business. He created his own landscaping business, so he would have flexible hours and go on all my field trips and be my girl scout leader. We were hit by the recession hard, in 2007 we were evicted from our home and my dad lost his business. He had to rely on his second job to now become his full time job. I lived with friends for the last six months of my senior year. We have landed back on our feet for the most part though. The Capri came home three years ago and has just sat, because we have not had enough extra money to even give it a new paint job.

I want to be able to do this for my dad, so he can enjoy it in his years to come. I love him so much and am grateful of all the sacifices he has made for me.
Plus then I will finally get to work on a car that is not my primary mode of transportation. Hopefully we can get it done by Father's Day of next year!

I appreciate any donation you can make, no matter how small. A little goes a long way when we all help! If you cannot afford to help, please spread the word about this fundraiser!

Thank you, with love,

Katie

story:
Hi I'm Keith; a career technologist, software developer, and video producer.

I was just selected by Google to join their Project Glass Explorers!!
 
This is the 1st opportunity for the public to try Google's new amazing technology - Google Glass!  Google Glass is the beginning of hands-free wearable computers; bringing the Internet, photography and personal communications directly to your field of view of the real world!
 
This is my chance to bring Google Glass to Orlando and investigate possible applications for the handicapped, create  unique first-person perspective videos (I live in Orlando, the theme park capital of the world, so imagine the possibilities), share my experiences, give others a chance to see Google Glass, explore the social and privacy concerns, and recommend improvements to Google since I will have their ear during this program. For example: In Epcot I will be able to actively explore the foreign language translation with native people from 8 different countries.

You can help!

It's a dream opportunity and I have lots of ideas. I'm excited to do the work. Unfortunately the downside of this golden ticket is I'm required to purchase the product and fly to NY to be fitted and trained. This crowd funding effort is to find some sponsors and me afford this:
  • Google Glasses will cost me $1500 Dollars + Tax (est $105)
  • Travel costs to NY are between $500-$800 

I'm looking for financial support and sponsorship for this unique opportunity. No amount is too small or too large. Any surplus raised will go to helping friends in the program with their costs, or be applied to my project expenses (travel, meals, etc.). Any after that will be donated to the United Way charity.

The Impact of Your Help

The bottom line is that with your support I can share my experiences, try a lot of creative ideas, explore the social aspect of wearing it to places, report my experiences, share some amazing first-person videos (I live near Disney World, Sea World, and NASA), see how useful it is for the handicaped, identify bugs and report them so others don't have to, and more. It's also your opportunity to be associated early with the recognition and excitement of this world changing technology.
 
I will be blogging as well as posting on Google+, sharing photos on Facebook and Tumblr, and videos on YouTube, and hosting regular Google+ hangouts. I'll be including the tags #keithbarrettsglass and #glassexplorers as appropriate. I am in the process of setting up the web sites now.
 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share my fund raising attempt with other people. Invite me to your Hangout shows to share my experiencves. Get the word out! Every bit helps!
 
 
Thank You For Your Consideration!
 
Note: Perks are generaly limited to the duration of this project, which I am planning as Dec 1st 2013 until Google provides more program details. If you select full sponsorship or IRL Meetup, I will make every effort to work with you on what's possible. In all situations I will not violate constraints of any Google NDA for the program.

story:
Summary

Hi everyone!  My name is Stephany Qiouyi Lu, and I'm a 21-year-old Chinese-American amateur photographer & graduate student.  I've been accepted into the Columbus Arts Festival's Emerging Artists Program; this June, I will be exhibiting and selling my photography for the first time on the beautiful downtown Riverfront in Columbus, Ohio.  This is a huge opportunity for me, and I'm extremely excited for this new experience!

A little bit about me: I've been interested in photography for a while, starting with little point-and-shoots that I played with as a preteen.  Eventually, a couple years ago, my dad handed down his Nikon D40x DSLR to me, sparking a more serious interest in photography.  I tend to focus on landscapes and do my best to capture the natural beauty of the scene I see before me.  99% of my photos come straight out of my camera with absolutely no editing!  You can view my photos on my website at http://stephany.qiouyi.lu/

As an individual and an amateur, I have to start from scratch for this exhibit.  Your contributions will help me acquire supplies and stock for the festival; with my limited graduate student budget, I can only go so far by myself.  But your contributions will help enormously!

What I Need

So here's how it all breaks down... these are the supplies and stock I'll be bringing to the festival, and about how much it'll all cost:

Display Supplies

  • Five knock-down propanel displays with support and hanging fixtures
  • One print bin
  • Two 24-pocket greeting card displays (for prints, cards, and postcards)
  • A business card holder
  • Literature displays for my artist's statement and prices
  • Total: ~$850

Sales Supplies

  • Cash box
  • Clipboards for preorder forms
  • Fire extinguisher
  • Pens
  • Staples
  • Storage boxes
  • Total: ~$250

Stock

  • 5x7 matted prints
  • 8x12 matted prints
  • Postcards
  • 5x7 folded cards
  • 5x7 framed prints
  • 8x12 framed prints
  • Total: ~$1,250

Any funding beyond my goal will go toward more stock, and 10% of that extra funding will be donated to my mental health & disability support fund.

What You Get

Perks are listed to the right.  Please feel free to visit my Flickr to choose the photos you'd like prints of!  You can either leave a comment or e-mail me at helena[at]mintlycafe.com with the photo(s) you'd like a print of; if e-mailing me, please remember to include your name as displayed on Indiegogo!  If you don't specify photos, I will send you one of my choosing :)

Other Ways You Can Help

You can still help even if you can't contribute monetarily!  Signal boosts and letting friends and family know about my campaign are always appreciated.  Indiegogo has a number of share tools you can use on various social networking websites :)

story:
Introduction

TWLOHA is a movement and organization dedicated to raising awareness and education of mental health issues. It is also dedicated to opening up the conversation about these problems, which include depression, addiction, self-injury, and suicide, in order to reduce the stigma that surrounds them. These are pervasive problems that affect more people than we realize.

When TWLOHA presents at college campuses, the impact is remarkable. Students come together as one community and are able to open up to each other, building trust and hope. The speakers open up the conversation by explaining TWLOHA's story, as well as each of their own. They discuss ways to end the stigma surrounding mental illness and they open up the floor for those who have come to the event to share their own stories.

It is with the goal of building community at the University of Hartford and opening up the conversation of what mental illness is actually like that Psi Chi would like to invite you to partner with us in bringing TWLOHA to the University of Hartford campus in the spring.

What We Need & What You Get

In order to bring TWLOHA to campus, we need to raise $3500. This money goes toward all expenses TWLOHA will need covered (airfare, meals, ground transportation and hotel). 

If we are unable to raise the full $3500 through Indiegogo, that money will still go toward bringing TWLOHA to campus. The board members are fundraising on our campus as well to ensure that we meet our goal!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to donate to, that is okay too! We ask that you spread the word and let others know about our campaign! Indiegogo has some very accessible share tools that make this easy for you!

story:
My name is Brian Goodman and I’m a PHD student and teaching fellow at Harvard University. I am raising $5,000 so that I can go to Liberia with Academics Without Borders Canada (AWBC) to teach English workshops at the University of Liberia in Monrovia. Please watch my video to find out more and contribute today. 

The project...

A decade after the end of the Second Liberian Civil War, the University of Liberia is still rebuilding. Although the university has many needs, this AWBC project, through a series of workshops, will improve  the language skills of all the instructors in the Department of English - teaching 70 instructors who in turn will teach 17,000 students each year. 

Providing training to the university’s instructors will have the broadest possible impact for English department students. Most of these students have achieved only a basic level of English. This is made more difficult by the reality that instructors in the English Department have wildly different levels of education. While most instructors have at least a bachelor’s degree in English from a local university, not all do. Through our workshops, we will expose instructors to a level of training that would otherwise be unavailable to them, improving both their English skills and teaching ability.

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise $5,000 to support this project. Funds will be used to send me to Liberia for four weeks - my flight and  travelling expenses, insurance, workshop expenses and a local living stipend for the duration of the volunteering period. I will not be paid a wage while I am there and am volunteering my time and expertise. 

Please click on the contribute now button so that, together, we can improve the skills and abilities of thousands of students at the university in order to build a brighter future for themselves, and for Liberia. Thank you!

We have some great perks, ranging from letters and photos from Liberia to local handicrafts. 

The Impact

This project will have a huge impact for many Liberians, teaching 70 instructors who in turn will teach 17,000 students each year. Improving higher education in Liberia will help to train a new generation of professionals who, in turn, will make a brighter future for Liberia. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this campaign using the Indiegogo Share tools, so that more people can hear about our campaign. Have a great day!

story:
Every year, Rotary Youth Exchange volunteers send over 8,000 high school students around the world for a year to learn a new language, experience a new culture, and make friends and experiences that last a lifetime.

However, millions of high school students in the US and around the world, still think traveling the world is an unconquerable and far-off dream. There is no way for our middle-aged Rotary volunteers to get to every classroom in every state in every country to tell them about this opportunity- this dream Rotary volunteers make a reality. Even if they are able to make it there, their information packed powerpoints are outdated, unexciting, and uninspirational- everything Rotary Youth Exchange isn't. 

The question arose: "How can we show these kids what they're missing?" 

Withpast Youth Exchange students dispersed to different states and current ones attending school in other countries or too busy living the dream here in the states to attend school presentations, the only answer is to make a series of promotional documentaries with real youth exchange students showing what its like and talking directly to the high school students they used to be.

Problem is...we don't have the equipment or the travel costs to take on such a project.

Rotary Youth Exchange Florida is a volunteer non-profit organization. All of the money we raise, we spend on our annual orientations to prepare the kids for their exchange year. We are unique as a youth exchange program in that we try to keep the costs as low as possible (up to $15,000 less than our for-profit competitors) and offer plenty of scholarships and sponsorships to future outbound students. We firmly believe that anyone that wants to go should be able to. 

That's why this project is so important. We need to get the word out. Random and far-between presentations and word of mouth are not cutting it. High School Students need to know that they too can partake in this life-changing experience- not in college, not when they're retired, but now! 

If this project is funded, the creator, a past youth exchange student from the US to Italy 2009-2010, will purchase the necessary professional equipment needed (a Canon XA10 Professional Camcorder, a Short Shotgun Microphone, a Wind Muff, and Final Cut Pro) and interview and gather video clips from past, current, and future youth exchange students, and even host families whose lives have been turned around by Rotary Youth Exchange. During post-production, she will edit the footage into five promotional videos that vary in length in order to accommodate different school's needs and allow for them to be easily shared on social networks.

This equipment will remain with Rotary Youth Exchange Florida for years that follow, allowing for orientations and speeches to be filmed and shared to contribute to our (hopefully) growing awareness. 

With your support, we hope to reach thousands of students who have no idea that their dream can become a reality. That they too can explore the world we all live in but barley know. That they as high school students can live abroad, can find themselves, and can experience what the world has to offer them. 

That is our dream. These videos are only the beginning. 

 

For more information visit ryeflorida.org
story_txt:
Every year, Rotary Youth Exchange volunteers send over 8,000 high school students around the world for a year to learn a new language, experience a new culture, and make friends and experiences that last a lifetime.
However, millions of high school students in the US and around the world, still think traveling the world is an unconquerable and far-off dream. There is no way for our middle-aged Rotary volunteers to get to every classroom in every state in every country to tell them about this opportunity- this dream Rotary volunteers make a reality. Even if they are able to make it there, their information packed powerpoints are outdated, unexciting, and uninspirational- everything Rotary Youth Exchange isn't.

story:
Phi Delta Theta was organized with three principle objectives:

The cultivation of friendship among its members, the acquirement individually of a high degree of mental culture, and the attainment personally of a high standard of morality.


We are the Alpha Lambda class of the Florida Mu chapter, dedicated to achieving to all three objectives listed above. Aside from learning to become better men, our chapter is devoted in supporting research and treatment for Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS), or better known as Lou Gehrig's disease. 


As students of Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University, our majors span from Aerospace Engineering to Aeronautical Science. We share a passion for aviation and assisting others in any way possible. 


The Phikeia Education Program teaches us how to become the greatest version of ourselves. We strive to become better men and to grow as brothers. Giving back to those affected by ALS is just one way we can make a difference. 


Any contribution counts, as we cannot raise the necessary funds alone.

Aside from learning to become better men, our chapter is devoted in supporting research and treatment for Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS), or better known as Lou Gehrig's disease. As students of Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University, our majors span from Aerospace Engineering to Aeronautical Science. We share a passion for aviation and assisting others in any way possible. The Phikeia Education Program teaches us how to become the greatest version of ourselves. We strive to become better men and to grow as brothers. Giving back to those affected by ALS is just one way we can make a difference. Any contribution counts, as we cannot raise the necessary funds alone.

story:
I'm Noah Carpenter! I am a sophomore at Saint Michael-Albertville High School. I have a big interest in meteorology and by attending the Cooperative Institute for Meteorological Satellite Studies (CIMSS) I can expand my knowledge about meteorology, as I will be attending college for a degree in this field.

Here is a description of this camp: 

The CIMSS Student Workshop on Atmospheric, Satellite, and Earth Sciences features an exciting five-day agenda in meteorology, astronomy, remote sensing and geology. Participating students stay on campus in lakeside dorms and experience science education, research and technology through hands-on activities, working directly with scientists, graduate students and professors.

Your support will help me raise enough money to cover my expenses for this camp. I want you to know that by participating in the meteorology camp, I will be able to add this to my applications for acceptance into a college or university and scholarships. 

Here is a breakdown of how I will utilize your contribution:

  • $75.00 will cover my registration fee.
  • $500.00 will cover my tuition.
  • $100 will cover transportation expenses.
  • The remaining amount will cover the fees associated with this website.

In addition to making a contribution, you can help me by posting this on your facebook page or by e-mailing it to your friends and family. 

Thank you for your support.

story:
A dear husband, father, grandfather, teacher, mentor and friend Ron Maggiano passed away unexpectedly May 19th from cancer related complications.

Passionate about education, music, God and his family, he leaves behind a legacy of compassion and, above all, love. We will celebrate his life with a memorial service on Saturday, May 31st at 10:00 am at Trinity Episcopal Church, 9108 John S Mosby Hwy, Upperville, VA.

In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the Ronald Maggiano Music Scholars program care of Emmanuel Church, Middleburg. Checks made payable to Emmanuel Episcopal Church, 105 E.Washington Street, Middleburg,VA 20117. Memo Line: Music Scholars.

Funding will go to support Music Students in the Piedmont and wider Northern Virginia areas with music, instruments, instruction, and if funds allow, scholarships so that they can continue to follow their dreams.

story:
Tuition Fundraising

Ivan and I have been studying in seminary for 4 years.  I have just finished my certificate this summer.  Ivan still has 30 credits to go and our 3rd kid is going to school this fall. 

外子與我同在神學院已四年.  我有幸今年剛完成我的証書課程, 但外子仍有三十個學分在讀.  我們的小女子也將於 9 月入讀學前班.

Honestly we are still not sure where would God lead us in the future.  God hasn't tell us where or in what we will serve.  Ivan has a strong feeling (or possibly calling?) that he would be serving college students.  We attend the Chinese Community Church at Washington D.C.  Besides serving at church, Ivan lead Bible study at home helping non-believer and I help kids in low income families to learn to play piano. 

說實的, 我們還未知道主將來要差派我們往那裡去.  外子一直有感動要服侍大專學生.  我們現在在美京中華基督教會事奉.  除了在教會事奉, 外子在家舉辦查經班幫助未信主之家庭, 而我則教授低收入家庭的兒童學習彈鋼琴.

Ivan is studying a Master of Divinity program with a pastoral focus and has finished 2/3 of the program.  We have been paying every cents of our studies in the past two years.  We are still expecting to pay US$13,000 in tuition and US$5,000 for room and board before he can graduate.  The tuition burden is getting intense from time to time.  We are hoping to raise just enough money for his next class on August 2014 (Hebrew III).  He has been maintaining his GPA around 3.79 (out of 4.0) so far.

現在外子是神學碩士在讀, 主修是教牧, 已完成課程的三分之二.  過去兩年我們沒有拿任何資助自付學費.  現在還要大概一萬三千美元學費和五千美元的交通住宿費才能完成整個課程.  這次籌款盼望可籌得 8 月要修讀的希伯來文III的學費.  外子成績一直維持在 3.79 (4.0 是滿分) 左右.

We have three little kids and we believe in Christian education as a caregiver to our kids.  Our 7-year-old and our 4-year-old are studying in private Christian schools.  Our 3-year-old daughter will join the journey in Christian education this Sept.  Our seminary study along with my high-risk pregnancies has been such a blessing.  We learned to pray and read and worship together as a family.  There had been very difficult moments in facing Joshua’s asthma and Katie’s serious eczema.  Katie’s condition has been so bad that it would have been prevent her in going to school this year.  We experienced God’s healing and the supports of brothers and sisters with lots of prayers and help.  Katie’s skin has been improved a lot this year.  Most importantly we have experienced God’s grace through this.  Even Nathan is extremely thankful for Katie’s situation.

我們育有三個小孩, 我們相信將孩子信到教會學校是主所喜悅的.  大兒子 (7 嵗) 跟次子(4嵗) 都已在基督教的私校就讀.  女兒 (3嵗) 亦將於9 月加入基督教學校.  在讀時的兩次高危懷孕成為我們很大的祝福.  我們學會了一家人一起祈禱, 讀經, 和敬拜.  謙謙的哮喘和妹妹的濕疹讓我們經歷主的醫治和弟兄姐妹的關愛.  大家的禱告和偏方 (豬油, 馬油, 亞麻子油, 大麻子油等等) 都為我們帶來很大的幫助.  妹妹的情況今年好多了.  本來以為她今年不能入學, 因著主的醫治, 她也準備上學了, 就連晟仔也讚嘆主醫治了妹妹.

Anything would help.  It would be great if you could share this page with others who may be interested in sponsoring a seminary student.  We trust that God will have a way.  Every classes in the seminary has been a faith builder to us.  We hope we could finish it strong so that we could be better equipped when we are called to serve Him full time in the future.  Thank you very much!

任何的幫助我們都無限感激.  請把這網頁與其他人分享.  我們深信主必供應.  在神學院的每一課程對我們都有極大造就.  希望將來能幫助我們全職事奉.  謝謝各位!

story:
What's this all about?

To sum it up as simple as possible, I'm a 16 year old student in high-school that applied for the Congress-Bundestag Youth Exchange scholarship to go to Germany for a year and study abroad. 

The scholarship covers all of the cost of airfare, travel (in the country), and other things such as medical insurance. Unfortunately, however, it does not cover domestic travel, or money to purchase clothes, toiletries, or other spending money I will need over there! The domestic travel is a big one as I have to come up with funds to get myself to and from Washington D.C., coming from the middle of the country in Nebraska. Donating even a small amount would mean a lot to me, as it would assist me in living out one of my biggest dreams, which has been to go over to Germany and study German in the country.

I'm very excited to go but I don't want to worry about having trouble with money, and I don't want to worry about being a burden to my host family!

So... Why so much?

I put $4000, as the recommended spending amount monthly is roughly $300 a month, and being there for 12 months, I will need approximately $3600. The extra amount is for the domestic travel to go to and from Washington DC.

I plan to take a ton of pictures, and I certainly plan to share them all around social media and show them to friends. I hope to make this an extremely productive study trip and learn a lot about Germany while I'm over there!

Even if I don't hit the entire goal of $4000, any money I do raise will help me pay for expenses!

The Impact

The idea behind my campaign is not only for me, but for all those around me. A lot of people want the kind of opportunity I have gotten from this scholarship, but don't know where to start. Even as of now, before I've even left, I've already inspired two of my friends to apply to be a foreign exchange student, to different countries all around the world. 

As Mark Twain said, "Broad, wholesome, charitable views of men and things cannot be acquired by vegetating in one little corner of the Earth all one's lifetime." I believe that quote really applies, because living in small town America, I know a lot of people that have never even been to another state that doesn't border ours, let alone been to another country. I feel like the impact I could make to inspire others to travel, study abroad, and just learn about other cultures will be amazing,

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't fund, and you know what? That's okay! I appreciate any support you have to give me, any kind words, or even advice for those that have traveled before! I also ask that you spread the word to friends of yours that may be able to donate, and I thank you for taking your time to read all of this!

story:
I am Nilgun, I studied Political Sciences in Istanbul, and then I moved to Poland for one year to volunteer and do charity work.

Now I have been accepted to a Sociology Masters degree at the FU Berlin. I am very into documentary cinema, women's rights, and migration issues. I am hoping to specialize my studies within these topics and keep studying as much as possible. 

For 2 years I have been trying to get to Berlin. It is the place where I believe I can pursue my work and my dreams with more self-confidence. During my visa application process I dealt with a lot of financial and other difficulties, and the process still did not end.

When I get my Visa, I will be a resident and student in Germany, which will give me a chance to survive here. Yet, I need a little push to make it possible for the first month. Because I worked as a volunteer during the last year, I do not have any savings. And I have already spent what I had left on all of those papers I needed to gather to be eligible for my visa application.

So, dear people, I am just asking for your support to be able to pay my rent for the first month, and have a basic standard of living (essentially feeding myself :) ) for a short. So this money you would donate for me will go to my very basic life expenses.

I understand that with so many other necessities this might seem a little bit like a luxury, but on the other hand I do not want to go back from this point as I am so close to my goal here.

This campaign is valuable to me, because I can see with your generous support my dream will come true. 

I would appreciate if you could share this & help me raise my voice!

story:
NOTE
If SEND does get created and "launched", the proceeds from this campaign will go directly to the Colleen Ritzer Scholarship Fund.  If SEND gets "Launched," a portion of the proceeds from the SEND System will be donated also to various charities combating "School Violence." 


            >> Prototype Design Picture and Feature Descriptions <<

Our Mission

My name is Joe Spanos, and I was a proud educator for over 30 years, lately I have seen and heard of way too many tragedies in our schoolhouses, and I feel the need to increase school safety in our buildings is a must. To sit back and not be proactive would be a travesty. 

Two recent local and tragic events that hit “close to home” which made me realize how important it is to assist in securing our schools were:  the “mass-shooting rampage” that horrifically killed 26 innocent 6 and 7-year-old children and staff at Sandy Hook Elementary School in New Town, CT.  My daughter was in the first grade when that tragedy occurred.

The second most recent “Unthinkable” act of violence was the brutal stabbing, raping and murdering of one of my former most beloved students at Andover High School; Colleen Ritzer.  Colleen was a beautiful soul and an angel on earth who wanted to be a Math Teacher and help shape the lives of our youth.  Her life was tragically taken at Danvers High School at the age of 24 by her fourteen year old student.  I have seen enough, as I’m sure you have, and would appreciate your assistance in minimizing and preventing these violent acts of terror in our schools. 


How Will SEND Make An Impact

To really appreciate the power of having such a device on hand requires you to imagine yourself as a teacher in a real classroom scenario.  Many teachers do not physically carry their cell phones on them during class.  It is either silenced on their desks, usually out of sight, or even secured within a purse that's placed under or inside the teacher's desk.  Keep in mind that teachers do not only sit at their desks, but actively move about the room helping students learn and tackle new concepts.  

When an attacker breaks into the classroom, there are but only a few seconds to react that could spell the difference between life and death.  With the best case of having a cell phone already in your pocket, you would still have to pull it out, select the emergency option, dial 9-1-1, and hope that you have reception or time long enough to connect to the operator.  During all of this, your focus was removed from your assailant; anything could have happened.  If the cell phone was in the desk and you are half way down the room, the attacker could be standing between you and your only lifeline.  

The SEND device is worn on the teacher at all times and with a quick press of one button, the emergency authorities are notified and the programmed alerts are immediately sent out.  This means that your focus could stay on your assailant the whole time, giving you more time to defend yourself and perform split-second decisions.  Additionally, having alerted the rest of the school, additional casualties could be significantly reduced.  That is the power of the SEND system.  Every fraction of a second counts.


Ways You Can Help

Please join our SEND team in assisting with the cost of the prototype and/or communicating to others through the means of “Social Media” and alike of our SEND product. Your contribution can help stop the violence and save lives now… 


Where Your Funds Will Make A Difference

All proceeds will be used towards building the SEND prototype system.  There will be a lot of custom software and hardware required and about $19,000 will go towards designing, coding, integrating, and testing the software and firmware of the SEND device and network prototypes.  $9,000 will go towards building the hardware of the SEND system.  This will include personal devices carried by the individuals, and also the custom network routers that will form the SEND network within a facility.  The remaining $2,000 will go towards marketing and business development.  Any additional money will go towards improving the SEND design to miniaturize the units and fund the mass production of them.  

As with any R&D, there is a higher cost up front.  Once the design and prototype are completed, the products themselves are much more affordable and will have low cost production and maintenance.


Benefits of SEND

*Protection for Students, Staff & Coaches with the Press of a Button
*Two Buttons - Three Features
*Instantly Alerting & Communicating with Emergency Response Personnel &    Administration
*Tracks & Transmits Voice Messages Instantly
*Every Second Counts
*Stay Connected - Never Alone
*Proper Installation Allows Entire Square Footage of Building to be Connected
  (Phone Reception Not Always Available, whereas SEND would be)
*Violence in our School Houses on the rise - Invest in Safety a must
*SEND can easily be attached to a name badge - discreet size of a USB Drive
*SEND allows you to Take Charge of an Emergency Situation, Immediately
*Instant Two-Way Communication enables Emergency Personnel to assist in the situation, be it a Heart Attack
*SEND is a Deterrent (Signs Stating This Building is Protected by SEND)


Check out the Gallery Tab for a picture of the prototype and a file that describes how the device works and its features!

===============================================================


General Questions

Who would be using the SEND device?

Teachers and staff members would be the ones wearing the device.  Generally, students are within the vicinity of adult supervision, so it makes sense to give the control to the teacher or staff.  We did consider children wearing the units, but that would potentially cause too many false alarms.  We recommend this to be used by adults only to minimize misuse.  Ultimately, it would be up to the school(s) to decide.

What was the reasoning behind choosing Indiegogo?

Our most compelling reason is because Indiegogo allows entrepreneurs to bring their ideas to the table and ask for support without having a prototype already built.  We have the idea, but still need the funding to build our first prototypes.  Sites like Kickstarter requires people to have the prototypes completed before asking for contributions.


Engineer's Corner

Why wouldn't a cell phone be the easy solution?

We asked ourselves the same question in the beginning, and realized that a cell phone had too many limitations for this type of use.

1. Many people have different types of phones, running different mobile OS and varying hardware and firmware specs.  Based on our expertise, to make a universal app would be too complex in keeping up with the multitude of software and hardware platforms. We wanted to take a different direction with the goal of providing a complete solution.  

2. Not everyone carries their cell phones with them at school.  Some facilities consider cell phones as a distraction and may prohibit them to be used at certain times.  The SEND device is always on and immediately reacts upon a press and will not pose as a classroom distraction.  

3. Smart phones are required to be recharged every 2 to 3 days.  We want our device to be free of that requirement.  The personal SEND unit will last for months without recharge using low power consumption techniques.

4.  It's faster to press one button under duress.

What is the form factor of the unit?

The wearable unit will be about the size of a USB thumbdrive.

Do you have outside support?

We are working with a team of engineers.  These are professional  engineers with extensive experience in hardware, software, firmware, design, integration, and testing.  They are on standby pending funding from this campaign.

What constraints do you have?

We spent a lot of time thinking about the obstacles that we will face moving ahead with a prototype design.

1. Cost: Generally, to accomplish what we are asking for would require a lot more money.  After reviewing our options and considering different individuals, we chose to move forward with the proposal from expert and reputable engineers based on their reasonable costs and their full belief in our cause.

2. Time: The sooner we are able to complete this project, the sooner we can potentially save lives.  Based on our needs, we took this approach because we believe that it is the most efficient path to get the product to the market.

3. Broadcasting Frequency: We do not want to violate any federal regulations, so we will be working within the spectrum of frequency designated for public use that will not interfere with any other RF systems and remain within federal guidelines.
story_txt:
NOTEIf SEND does get created and "launched", the proceeds from this campaign will go directly to the Colleen Ritzer Scholarship Fund.  If SEND gets "Launched," a portion of the proceeds from the SEND System will be donated also to various charities combating "School Violence."

story:
The Book

"Fundo's Animal Alphabet" is an alphabet book for early childhood readers, ages 2 through 6.  In the story, the main character Fundo takes the reader on an adventure, teaching kids their ABCs and meeting interesting animals along the way.

Our Story

Hi, my name is Garry and I am an artist and the creator of "Fundo's Animal Alphabet".  I created the character, Fundo, as a tool to teach kids in a way that is exciting and engaging.  Earlier this year, I co-wrote and illustrated my first book, "Fundo's Animal Alphabet", an exciting story for early childhood readers.  

My goal with this campaign is to raise funds in order to self publish this book, through my imprint Fundo Press.  I'm passionate about this book because it promotes learning and creativity among young readers.  As a visual learner, I know the importance of good illustrations in helping kids learn.  Early childhood education has a huge effect on a child's future.  I know that this book will make a great impact on young readers.   

In order to make this book available to the world, I need the support of others who believe in this message.  Your support can help make this book a great success.  This is an opportunity to teach kids their ABC's in a fun, engaging way.


What We Need & What You Get

Provided that we reach our campaign goal of raise $7,000, we will use the money for:

  • Printing Cost of the 1st edition
  • Marketing Costs
  • Publishing Costs (ISBN Numbers for retail sale)
  • Editing Costs
  • Additional resources (shipping costs, taxes, formatting costs)

Your contributions can make this book a reality!  We are asking you to please support our goal of enriching the minds of the future.  This book has the power to empower the youth by inspiring them to learn more!  We created this book to custom-fit a young generation of children that have all the potential in the world.  As a new uncle, I want my niece and other kids to have access to learning resources that are both fun and effective in developing their reading ability.  

For supporting "Fundo's Animal Alphabet", you will be rewarded with the exclusive perks, listed to the right. These perks include limited edition items including sketches from the creation of Fundo, signed copies of the book, and your name listed in the credits!

Fundo is sure to be a huge character that lasts for generations.  These cool perks are sure to be collectible items that are very valuable years from now.  

If we do not reach our campaign goal, we will continue towards publishing this book. However, we will need to postpone the production of the books, until we can raise the needed funds.  

If we exceed our goal, the additional funds will go towards making the next early childhood book in the Fundo Press collection:

"Fundo's Shape Factory"

"Fundo's Vegetable Voyage"

"Fundo's Counting 1-2-3"


The Impact

"Fundo's Animal Alphabet" is a book that is:

  • Helpful for strengthening the vocabulary of young readers
  • Bringing kids up to speed with their peers
  • Packed with plenty of exciting illustrations
Affordability

  "Fundo's Animal Alphabet" will be a book that is affordable for every household.  I think it is important that every child has access to quality early childhood books.  Studies show that:

There is a gap in vocabulary knowledge between economically disadvantaged and economically advantaged children that begins in preschool and is an important correlate of poor school performance. (Blachowicz et al, 2006)

By supporting this book, you can positively contribute towards the future of many children's education.


Other Ways You Can Help

Share our Indiegogo page with your Facebook friends

Tweet our Indiegogo campaign to your followers

Email your friends the link to our Indiegogo campaign

Post comments on our Indiegogo campaign

Follow our Indiegogo campaign to receive updates


Previews from "Fundo's Animal Alphabet":

story:
Every Child Deserves A Chance

COMMUNITY LIBRARIES ARE A SOURCE OF HOPE

A child with access to a community library is 300% more likely to complete her primary education.

 

Hi, I'm Joe Hafner, Founder of Go For Hope and the guy that started this campaign. In 2010, I moved my family to Nicaragua after losing almost everything in the recession. Living there for nearly a year transformed my life: Despite my own losses, I learned to embrace gratitude and was filled with a desire to serve the most vulnerable. When we returned to the U.S. I started Go For Hope to share the joy of service and giving. This is our first crowd funding campaign, and I hope you will join us in giving the gift of education and hope to these children.

Where does the money go?

This campaign is to fund two library programs in very specific ways:

Program 1: El Comedor (The Community Soup Kitchen)

  At the northern edge of the city of Matagalpa sits a small plot of land burned by the equatorial sun. Two years ago, a Catholic nun approached the owners of the land about creating a safe place for the many impoverished boys and girls in the neighborhood. At first, they provided a simple sanctuary from the dangers of the streets. Soon, a basic meal was offered in return for good behavior. Now, several hundred children visit El Comedor each week to receive the love, care and attention that every child deserves. The all-volunteer staff at El Comedor wants to offer these students more by building a library and homework center on the premises. They need the following: 
  • Security improvements to the existing fence: $1200
  • Building improvements: $3400
  • Tables, chairs: $450
  • Secure cabinets for book storage: $875
  • Educational supplements: $800
  • Seed collection of children's titles: $500
  • Library-in-a-box lending system: $250
  • Librarian training: $600
  • Basic art and education supplies: $375
Total: $8450
 

Project 2: El Volador (The Flying Book, mobile library)

On the outskirts of Estelí, in the ranching and tobacco-growing region of northern Nicaragua, sit a series of small disconnected farming villages. Too far from the city center, these communities rely on the mobile library truck to bring not just books, but medical, vision and dental necessities to vulnerable residents. El Volador currently serves 800 children on a bi-monthly rotation. Twice that many are not receiving any services at all. With some help, they can offer services to more than 2500 children by adding a second route. To accomplish this, they need the following: 
  • Improvements to the current vehicle: $4400
  • Additional books for current route: $450
  • Training for a second mobile librarian: $600
  • Seed collection of children's titles for second route: $500
  • Library-in-a-box lending system for second route: $250
  • Adult literacy program supplies: $475
Total: $6675

Stretch goals and future projects

If we surpass our funding goal, our next target is $22,500. This would allow us to build, supply and train the staff for a library at a boarding home for teenage boys who have been rescued from the streets.

 

In Nicaragua…

  • Out of 100 children who start the first grade this year, 51 of them will complete the 5th grade.
  • The average Nicaraguan adult aged 25-40 has 4.6 years of formal schooling.
  • Nicaragua spends $62 per year per student.  In contrast, the United States spends an average of $10,600.
  • Lack of training and low income cause many teachers to abandon their profession.


HELP US BUILD A COMMUNITY LIBRARY

Poverty is the greatest threat to the welfare of Nicaraguan children.
    More than 2/3 of the population earns an average of $100 per month. 
  • Unlike the United States, children in Nicaragua are often pressured to leave school as early as 8 years old to help the family earn income or perform domestic duties. 
However, a student that completes her primary education
  • Will earn 1.4 times more than her less-educated peers. 
  • Each year of education beyond the 5th grade is correlated with a 14% increase in monthly earnings. 

The Backstory

The first book I remember reading was "The Berenstain Bears: Bears in the Night". I can still feel the excitement and anticipation that built as my imagination carried me out my window, down the tree, over the wall, and under the bridge, off on an adventure into the night. Classic children's tales are a staple of early education in the U.S. and foster a love of exploration and discovery through reading. Frankly, I'd taken books for granted for most of my life...   


A Story begins...

 

On August 12th, 2010, my wife, three children and I left friends, relatives and everything familiar behind and boarded a plane bound for Nicaragua, a little-known Spanish-speaking country in Central America. We had lost our home after a two year battle against the recession, and we needed a change. We had brains in our heads and shoes on our feet, and that was about it. We abandoned our suburban lifestyle for nearly a year to live as neighbors in the 2nd poorest country in the Western Hemisphere. We helped where we could and discovered the importance of dignity in cross-cultural relationships.

One sunny afternoon we visited a rural school on a mobile library truck. Children of all ages burst with excitement at our arrival. They crowded around a makeshift table, eyes drinking in the vibrant book covers laid out before them. I learned that thanks to this little pick-up truck and a few hundred children's titles, these children could check out two books per month. Before the library was started, they had none. For these students, books were a luxury.


The Next Chapter...

Six months after returning to the United States I started Go For Hope. Our mission: to improve the quality and access to education for children in the most disadvantaged regions of Nicaragua by partnering with indigenous programs such as community libraries and learning centers. With the support of a small but dedicated team of volunteers and donors, we have donated more than 1000 books and partnered with several Nicaraguan organizations in support of education. But there is much more to do. We need your help to expand the programs that we currently support, and reach more children who thirst for a quality education.

Nicaragua spends $62 per year per student.  In contrast, the United States spends an average of $10,600.
Lack of training and low income cause many teachers to abandon their profession.



HELP US BUILD A COMMUNITY LIBRARYPoverty is the greatest threat to the welfare of Nicaraguan children.More than 2/3 of the population earns an average of $100 per month. Unlike the United States, children in Nicaragua are often pressured to leave school as early as 8 years old to help the family earn income or perform domestic duties. 
However, a student that completes her primary education
Will earn 1.4 times more than her less-educated peers. 
Each year of education beyond the 5th grade is correlated with a 14% increase in monthly earnings. 


The Backstory 
The first book I remember reading was "The Berenstain Bears: Bears in the Night". I can still feel the excitement and anticipation that built as my imagination carried me out my window, down the tree, over the wall, and under the bridge, off on an adventure into the night. Classic children's tales are a staple of early education in the U.S. and foster a love of exploration and discovery through reading. Frankly, I'd taken books for granted for most of my life...   
A Story begins...
 


On August 12th, 2010, my wife, three children and I left friends, relatives and everything familiar behind and boarded a plane bound for Nicaragua, a little-known Spanish-speaking country in Central America. We had lost our home after a two year battle against the recession, and we needed a change. We had brains in our heads and shoes on our feet, and that was about it.
We abandoned our suburban lifestyle for nearly a year to live as neighbors in the 2nd poorest country in the Western Hemisphere. We helped where we could and discovered the importance of dignity in cross-cultural relationships.
One sunny afternoon we visited a rural school on a mobile library truck. Children of all ages burst with excitement at our arrival. They crowded around a makeshift table, eyes drinking in the vibrant book covers laid out before them. I learned that thanks to this little pick-up truck and a few hundred children's titles, these children could check out two books per month. Before the library was started, they had none. For these students, books were a luxury.


The Next Chapter...

Six months after returning to the United States I started Go For Hope. Our mission: to improve the quality and access to education for children in the most disadvantaged regions of Nicaragua by partnering with indigenous programs such as community libraries and learning centers.
With the support of a small but dedicated team of volunteers and donors, we have donated more than 1000 books and partnered with several Nicaraguan organizations in support of education. But there is much more to do.
We need your help to expand the programs that we currently support, and reach more children who thirst for a quality education.

story:
After reading their last book, Speak, my English students at Phillipsburg High School were inspired to raise money for survivors of rape. And, if they can raise $1000 in the next 2 weeks, then they will be able to Skype with the author.

We decided to support RAINN (Rape, Abuse, & Incest National Network) because it “is the nation's largest anti-sexual violence organization and was named one of ‘America's 100 Best Charities’ by Worth magazine. RAINN created and operates the National Sexual Assault Hotline (800.656.HOPE and online.rainn.org) in partnership with more than 1,100 local rape crisis centers across the country and operates the DoD Safe Helpline for the Department of Defense. RAINN also carries out programs to prevent sexual violence, help victims, and ensure that rapists are brought to justice” (RAINN).

By supporting this fundraising venture, you are helping survivors of rape, promoting creative writing, and proving that youth can positively impact society.

To encourage you to donate, my students are willing to write.

The first 15 donators of $5 will receive a student written metaphor or simile.

The first 10 donators of $10 will receive a student written 100 word poem.

The first 5 donators of $25 will receive a student written short story.

The first 3 donators of $100 will receive a student written poem and an accompanying sketch.

After the funding has ended, my students will write each piece and I will send the work to you via email.

All proceeds will go to RAINN.

Thank you for your generosity.
