story:
Our Story

Hi! Aver School is a volunteer-run organization dedicated to teaching digital photo, video and audio skills to at-risk children around the world. Since 2006, we've been hosting an annual workshop at Esperanza Viva Youth Home in Puebla, Mexico.

The photos in the video above were taken by Aver School students. By donating, you will be giving them another opportunity to take more photos and continue to grow their skills.


The Impact

Too many children in the world (around 143 million of them according to 2005 UNICEF figures) find themselves facing life on their own, with little support from family. Kids that have no one to care for them experience great hardships, poverty, abuse, even death. Life really is a daily struggle for survival. 


The good news is that there is good news: All over the world there are people that care that are making a positive difference in the lives of at-risk children and youth.


Aver School partners with organizations, orphanages and youth homes that give at-risk children a brighter future by providing food, shelter, health care, an education and most of all love. We believe that in today's world, all children should have the opportunity to learn digital media skills and to have an outlet for their creativity and their voice.


What We Need & What You Get

We're raising $3,000 to buy five digital SLR cameras and to cover the costs for the upcoming workshop in November. Here's a breakdown of our needs:

  • $100 - Gallery Exhibit Expenses (frames, photo printing, food)
  • $100 - Photo Calendar prizes for kids from 2010 photos.
  • $800 - Transportation (Two $350 RT tickets to Puebla via Mexico City and $100 for local transport).
  • $2,000 - To buy 5 digital SLR cameras.

This year, Aver School teacher, Valentina Vitols and I will be going to Mexico. Normally we cover all expenses ourselves but currently our finances do not permit this so we are asking for help to pay for our travel expenses and raising additional funds to get much needed cameras for the kids. We've been using digital point-n-shoots and the students are ready to learn and use more advanced photography concepts.

10/28/2011 Update: Unfortunately, due to a family emergency, Valentina will not be able to go to Mexico this year. The kids and I will miss her greatly! Since I will be the sole workshop facilitator, we are tailoring the content and format to best match my skill set with the kids' learning needs. Additionally, any funds raised to cover Valentina's travel expenses will now be applied towards buying more cameras.

Donations to Aver School are 100% tax deductible in the USA.


Other Ways You Can Help

While our goal is to buy 5 digital SLR cameras, our dream is to get an additional 5 cameras donated (10 total), enabling more students to further their skills. You can help us by hosting a Camera Campaign which will help us get camera donations. Of course, one of the main ways that you can help is by spreading the word of this campaign far and wide!


Thanking you in advance for your support!


Ruth Hartmann

Aver School Founder

story:
SUPPORT OUR GROWTH

Give more kids in NYC the chance to empower themselves through music.

Last year we aimed to serve 120 kids.  Thanks to your support we reached over 500!

In response to the increasing demand for our programs, we are seeking your help to build a brand new mobile music studio and train more teachers in order to reach our ambitious yet achievable goal of serving 600+ kids in 2014. 

GOAL = $10,000

Here's the breakdown:

Studio Equipment

  • Laptop x2 --------------- $1,442
  • Software ---------------- $1,030
  • Keyboard --------------- $350
  • Cables & Adapters --- $206
  • Microphone x2 --------- $309
  • Speakers (set) -------- $429
  • Headphones x3 ------- $309
  • Audio Interface -------- $773
  • Dolly --------------------- $72
  • Carrying Case x3 ----- $232
  • Power Strip x2 --------- $21
  • Flip Camera ------------ $206
  • Boombox --------------- $155
  • Instruments ------------ $618
Supplies
  • White Board ----------- $52
  • Markers/Eraser ------- $21
Teachers
  • Training & Salary ----- $3775
                              TOTAL $10,000

"Students of lower socioeconomic status who took music lessons in grades 8–12 increased their math scores significantly as compared to non-music students. But just as important, reading, history, geography and even social skills soared by 40%"


Music education facilitates student academic achievement: Improves recall and retention of verbal information, boosts reading and English language arts (ELA) skills and improves average SAT scores

Music education develops the creative capacities for lifelong success: Sharpens student attentiveness, strengthens perseverance, equips students to be creative and supports better study habits and self-esteem.

Hang on a second I hear you say... What about the costs of staff, renting space, insurance and all those good things? Don't worry, we haven't forgotten.  We are also receiving donations from foundations, large checks from individual donors and can leverage our strategic partnerships to cover those other costs.  We need your help to cover the 'fixed costs' outlined above.  But, we don't think about it in term's of 'covering fixed costs', it's way, way cooler than that.  Here's a few sentences to sum up what your contribution means:

  • $25 pays for a Project Rhythm student to spend a day learning music and collaboration in the Project Rhythm Mobile Studio. SWEET!
  • $125 pays for a Project Rhythm student to spend a whole week learning music and collaboration and recording songs in the Project Rhythm Mobile Studio. AWESOME!
  • $1,000 pays for an entire group (15 students) to spend a week at the Project Rhythm Mobile Studio. You ROCK!

We really appreciate your contribution to helping Project Rhythm reach youth through the instrument of music and we want to show you how much.  Check out our PERKS on the right-hand side of this page!

Other Ways You Can Help

There are other ways you can help us rock the Project Rhythm mobile studio!  Why not:

  • Share the link to this page with your social circle: Facebook, Twitter, Email or Sing it from the rooftop!
  • Like us on Facebook or follow us on Twitter


SPECIAL THANKS TO

Bill and Melinda Gates Matching Gift Program, Gould Family Fund, Richard and Freya Block Family Foundation and to the dedicated team of amazing Project Rhythm volunteers and directors:

George Abar, Erica Allen, Emanuel Ayvas, Radhika Batra, Larry Buchanan, Mita Carriman, Chris Castiglione, Camus Celli, James Cody, Kaitlin Coffey, Lauren Cook, Nina Damato, Devang Doshi, Matt Doumar, Fafu, Samara Gaev, Jamin Gilbert, Zanna Gilbert, Carrie Gillispie, Ella Gudwin, Shireen Idroos, Ray Jones, Isa Loundon, Maddy Maxy, Jason Moses, Joseph Pineda, Bob Powers, Pamela Sam, Annetta Seecharran, Will Sentance, Diko Shoturma, Lauryn Soden, Laith Ulaby, and Sadatu Usman.

story:
Halloween Hoopla 5K Helps Children in Need

Annie Coons, Honorary Chair & Wife of U.S. Senator Chris Coons
invites you to make a difference. Help Delaware's children in need by supporting and attending the 5K!

Register to run at: www.bit.ly/hooplasignup


Short Summary

Kind to Kids Foundation is a nonprofit charity that makes dreams come true for foster children & children in poverty. We send children in need to wonderful events they could not normally attend, and provide Life Skills education programs.

Kind to Kids brightens the lives of needy children by giving them opportunities they would not otherwise have. We provide healthy, family friendly experiences for underprivileged children.  Often, the children can only imagine what it would be like to go to a symphony, theater, or a sports game. We make these dreams come true.  Come join us and make a difference!

Foster children have been removed from their homes because they were abused or neglected by their own families. Kind to Kids brings joy to a child in the midst of an extremely painful situation.  In our LifeSkills Program, we teach children how to be successful in life, and that their past does not equal their future. Every youth has their own unique and special strengths.

What We Need & What You Get

By attending the Halloween Hoopla, you will have the joy of participating in a fun-filled community event - and comfort of realizing that your contribution will bring happiness to a child in need who lives right in your community.

Kind to Kids Foundation is an extremely efficient and well respected, 501c3, nonprofit charity. The money raised will fund 3 services: 

1. Event opportunities for foster children and children in poverty

2. LifeSkills Program to teach foster teens how to be successful in the adult world.

3. Toys for foster children this Holiday Season. For many of the foster children, the toys we provide will be the only ones they get during the holidays. Last year we had a toy for every child (800) in Delaware's foster care system. We hope to bring joy again this year!

The Impact

This campaign gives Kind to Kids the funds to impact the lives of Delaware's children in need.

  • Through Kind to Kids, children attend events for the very first time. A thank you note from a boy in poverty who attended his very first baseball game writes, "May God bless you so very much."  Another child - who had been brutally beaten and is now in foster care - wrote to us after a wonderful day visiting Sesame Place. Her hearfelt note said, "This has been a day that I decided to live again."
  • One foster child who is attending our LifeSkills class wrote "Thank you for bringing light into my darkness."  What an amazing gift to give a child in pain.
  • Kind to Kids has an excellent track record of delivering quality services to Delaware's needy chidlren. Since 2008, we have delivered over 5,000 events to impoverished children at over $80,000 in ticket costs.
  • Kind to Kids is making a real difference in the lives of children who have so much hardship in their young lives. Visit us at kindtokids.org to learn more about how you can help...

Other Ways You Can Help

We need people to get the word out, sponsors, volunteers to work the event, and attendees!

  • We encourage you to support our campaign by using the Indiegogo share tools at top to help spread the word. Making more people aware of our campaign increases our chances of meeting our goals.
  • Get the word out through emails! Forward this link to friends and family:  http://www.indiegogo.com/halloweenhoopla?a=942869&i=emal
  • If you are unable to donate to our event you can attend our run on October 27th, 2012 by signing up at www.races2run.com.
  • Visit our website and educate yourself and others on services for foster children and youth in poverty at www.kindtokids.org.
  • If you would like to volunteer, or learn more about our services, please contact Catherine Pardo, Office Manager at: catherine@kindtokids.org or call (302) 654-5440.
  • If you would like to be a sponsor, plaese call Caroline Jones, Founder & Executive Director at carolinejones@kindtokids.org, or call (302) 654-5440.
  • Many thanks for your kindness and support! We appreciate all contributions both monetary and participatory as they give us the tools we need to impact the lives of children in need..

Visit our website and educate yourself and others on services for foster children and youth in poverty at www.kindtokids.org.
If you would like to volunteer, or learn more about our services, please contact Catherine Pardo, Office Manager at: catherine@kindtokids.org or call (302) 654-5440.

If you would like to be a sponsor, plaese call Caroline Jones, Founder & Executive Director at carolinejones@kindtokids.org, or call (302) 654-5440.
Many thanks for your kindness and support! We appreciate all contributions both monetary and participatory as they give us the tools we need to impact the lives of children in need..

story:
Authoring Action needs you to help provide our 12th consecutive 5 week Summer Intensive.  Our Annual Summer intensive is necessary to refresh our year-round Assegai Touring Ensemble, thus, sustain Authoring Action's very 2013-2014 existence.

Pitch Video

Featured Videos:

A Case For Literacy: Nathan Ross Freeman, Artistic Director

Harvard Graduate School of Education, April 28, 2012

Please view all our Literacy and Harvard Video Blogs

Authoring Action kicks off our 12th year working with teens who learn the power of their own voices through creative writing and engaging audiences of all sizes through stage and film. Over the first eleven years we've developed teens from high crime neighborhoods, teens who may be lacking one or more essential support systems, some teens who have great support but need to discover a sense of self and direction, high achievers and low achievers, across race and class. We are ... click:

Prime Directive

This summer, in 5 weeks, 20 teen apprentices and 8 teen peer-mentors will Write 100 Spoken Word Masterpieces - to produce and  present to The Triad in a 2 night event of Live Stage and Film Screening Extravaganza.  Our 2013 Summer Intensive brings together local professional artists and our teen authors to inspire and educate the greater human community...reaching beyond our neighborhood to yours.
Now 11 seasons, over 1,500 Literary pieces, 60 videos, 30 short films later, Authoring Action is on the eve of our 12th Summer Intensive.  

Authoring Action has achieved a keynote presenter status with over 50 local, regional, national and international civic, educational, faith based, cultural, law enforcement, judicial and health organizations. 

SUMMER INTENSIVE


Our grueling Summer Intensive is indeed that. (photos) We roll from 845 AM to 415 PM, Monday through Friday, during the end of June through July.  
Every morning begins with yoga, calisthenics, empowerment sharing.  
For the first 10 days we write our Shout Outs, Riffs, Poems, Monologues, Stories and Short Screenplays.  A collection of 110-150 pieces that must qualify as literary, stage, screen production and publication worthy.  Did I say gallery? Click:

Authoring Action Word Wall


The next 3 weeks our apprentice authors are drilled in Speech Conditioning, work with Collaborating Artists to develop 3 of their 120 writings for Spoken Word, Filmmaking, Songs, Choreography, Visual Arts.


The final week we Tech and Dress rehearse for our Commencement: our Community Celebration, show-off launching  of our new ensemble of middle and high school authors who will graduate into our elite year-round Assegai Ensemble and roll with us all the way into college.

Each Summer Intensive yields authors who transcend gender, ethnicity and class to achieve ... their name. I.E. self identification, a signature reference point and style. They go forth as Assegai and engage their audiences and readers eye-to-eye and have proven to impact human development and change.  Our audiences/readers leave with a mandate to do something.  Art Must Do Something.

When our audiences request Authoring Action to develop the themes of their events, they come to us for our teens to show them the way.

  "I am happy to be writing this letter of support for Authoring Action, as I have been continually inspired by the entrepreneurial acumen and artistic excellence of their organization. They are impresarios of community integration, and a beacon in the artistic ecology of this region – infusing the Triad, state and country with artistic energy, innovation, and camaraderie."
                ~ Steven Matijcio, Curator of South Eastern Center For Contemporary Art

What We Need

We need support for 4 areas of our summer institute.

YOUTH STIPENDS - $9,500.00

Authoring Action promotes positive and energetic work habits.  If you are working, you are earning…not only in the area of personal development, but financially as well.  Every teen apprentice author and peer mentor can earn up to $15.00 per day stipend which is totaled and paid at the end of the 5 weeks!  Stipends provide great incentive to work hard and to learn that one can be paid for their art form.


PROGRAM STAFF - $13,000.00

$2,500 ~ 5 weeks of Professional Teaching Artist Fees for 1 Artist
($75 will cover 1 artist fee for the 5 week institute per student)

$5,000 ~ Supports the Artistic Director fees – 5 weeks of planning and prep. For the summer institute, direction of the commencement and wrap-up.

$2,000 ~ Supports 5 weeks of part-time Professional Teaching Musician Fees  ($50 will cover 1 musician fee for the 5 week institute per student)

$1,500 ~ Provides 2 college interns to assist with program oversight.

$2,000 ~ Provides honoraria for 4 teen author mentors


 NUTRITION - $3,000.00

Every summer, Authoring Action provides healthy snacks and nutritious lunches made from scratch!  We work with local farms to provide fresh vegetables, dairy and meat  - and our chef  uses creative recipes - so that teens can learn about healthy eating.    (Costs include chef, food and supplies)


ADMINISTRATIVE SUPPORT - $5,500.00 

 Program Assistant and Executive support – Administrative/Program costs to support the institute’s organization/structure to ensure and maximize the apprenticeships and learning environment for our youth and artists

The Impact
Authoring Action’s Summer Intensive 2013 is a substantial contribution to youth and global youth movements.


- In an arena where contemporary presentations in every genre are eventually most celebrated in their final form as a video, film, web broadcast, Authoring Action’s Summer 2013 agenda is State of the Art.


- Our 2013 Summer Intensive targets regional and national Spoken Word engagements.

- In the 11 years Authoring Action has been active we have written more than 1,650 literary works, 53 short films, film blog clips. When you go to our store you will find we have produced a 500 page Anthology, an award winning Mr. Bones Feature Length Film, and an award winning Authoring Action Feature Length Documentary.


- Our live presentation engagements have educated thousands in the social, legal, civic, cultural, art education, alternative education, faith, crisis control, environmental and exceptional achievement arenas. Pleas visit our website.

“You’ll never know the flow of ink within the soul, spilling out into words and screams. Scream until you saturate the air with your voice. Stain the ears of kaleidoscopic canvases. Tell them I am here. Don’t make time, create time. Create life from words". ~ Tony Jenkins, 18, Authoring Action Assegai Outreach Ensemble

Other Ways You Can Help
We need you now, this moment and our cause is urgent. Our 2013 Summer Intensive needs to be financially solvent and we need to reach our goal for it to happen. We begin the first week of July and Present the first week of August. We have to achieve our goal in 45 days or less. Your sharing of our cause even in lieu of cash ... IS Cash. Please send someone to us who can make it happen.
story_txt:
Authoring Action needs you to help provide our 12th consecutive 5 week Summer Intensive.  Our Annual Summer intensive is necessary to refresh our year-round Assegai Touring Ensemble, thus, sustain Authoring Action's very 2013-2014 existence.

story:
A summary about us:

       We five teens, are an organization called Dedicated To Make a Change, which  based in Ypsilanti, MI. We are a group made up of teens, 12-18 years of age, that are interested in helping out our community. Most of our work consists of going on service trips to different parts of the country to volunteer in the community and to meet community members work. After Hurricane Katrina and the flooding we have gone to New Orleans. The work there is not finished.  We also work in Michigan (Detroit.) and Kentucky, (Lotts Creek.) In these places we rebuild homes, schools, community buildings and parks, build raised garden beds and plant garders and Wetlands Restoration.

We five teens, need your help to go back to New Orleans and continue all the volunteer work that still needs to be done. 

Why we are doing this work:

(A few words from  "We five teens.")

Debrieana: "Because I feel like it is important to show that there are people out there who still care, and to show that everything is still not better." 

Max: "Because I think that it is important to be able to help people and build community around our world. It makes the hardships of the world seem less terrible when we know we can really on one another to help eachother." 

Ayaka: "Because I think it is interesting to travel and meet new different kinds of people, plus I feel like service work is my calling, and the work I was meant to do."

Lizzie: "Volunteering is a passion of mine, it is always great to see the hope that our group can bring to people with the work we do." 

Allison: "I think it is important to help others, because it helps you to find yourself and figure out who you are." 

Nils: "I have been to New Orleans 5 times, and I keep going back because the work is still not done yet."

What your contribution will help us pay for:

 

-Buying food to cook with the ninth ward community.

-Train tickets to help us get to New Orleans.

-Supplies that we will need to buy to be able to fix homes.

- Our stay at the United Saints recovery project.

- Our transporation to get to different volunteer sights.

story:
Hi! My name's Ben, and this January I am hoping to go to Honduras with some friends of mine to help out with a volunteer organization called Honduras Children. They do a lot of work in a town called El Porvenir, expanding and improving the academic experience of about 200 local kids, and hopefully teaching them a variety of useful life lessons besides. Outside of their work in the classroom, Honduras Children does a lot of work in the local community, and I think I could make a real impact there if nowhere else (there's always a use for unskilled labor, right?). There's always work to be done and connections to be made with the local people, and they're doing a great job of not only doing that work, but giving guys like me the opportunity to do it too. In short there's a lot of worthwhile stuff being done down there, and I am ready, willing, and almost able to go and work my ass off with them. Wanna toss me a couple bucks?

All in all, I'm going to need a thousand dollars (about half for plane tickets, the other for living expenses while I'm there, renting a car, getting a passport, etc.) The plane tickets for my group were bought... yesterday, so the sooner I can get moving on that the better. Anything you can give will be much appreciated. So appreciated, in fact, that I will be unable to contain my unbridled appreciation and it will boil over into the form of a gnarly drawing of a kitty or something which I will then give to you. Along with a hug if you are within hugging distance. 

If I don't make enough, I'll give what I raised right to Honduras Children. They're a seriously cool group with some seriously cool volunteers (I know one of the founding directors, Eve Horowitz, and she's a very intelligent and productive person). Their Vacation Activities Program is especially awesome, the idea being to give kids  the opportunity to continure their education during their equivaent of summer break. It should be a testament to what a positive impact they're having that the kids are willing to come in to learn during their time off. That's just one example of the cool work they're doing, and if you want see more you should check out their website. 

Obviously the main benefit I'm trying to sell here is the useful stuff I'll be doing while I'm down there, but equally important (to me at least) is what I'll get out of it. I've never left the states in my life, sad to say, and though I don't speak much Spanish yet I see this as an invaluable opportunity to meet and bond with people from an entirely different background. Besides the new perspective, there's the new experiences, and those are equally invaluable. It's been my experience that hard work is good for your mind, and so is travel, and so is meeting new and interesting people. This is my chance at getting all three in one fell swoop.

So there you have it! That's my pitch. If you don't have money to give away, please remember that sending a few people this link can be just as valuable. If you do have money to give away, and you decide to give it away to me, you have my sincere and eternal gratitude. Seriously. This is definitely helpful for Honduras Children, but it's huge for me. All I can say is that someday I hope to be able to return the favor, and thank you, thank you, thank you!

story:
Background

Since 1982, Neighbrohood Ministries (NM) has been serving distressed families of urban Phoenix, advocating for their physical, emotional, mental and spiritual needs. Among the organization's many programs and ministries are a food and clothing bank, a pre-school, youth outreach, dance and guitar classes, a bike shop, college access and tutoring, community advocacy, support for teen moms - the list goes on and on. In a given week, over 700 children and young adults will connect with well over 100 volunteers both on our 8-acre property and also out in homes and surrounding neighborhoods seeking to foster healthy relationships and break cycles of brokenness, addiction, abuse and poverty. 

Summer Kids Club at the Neighborhood Center

 

While the majority of our year is spent mirroring a traditional school year of programming, the summer has continually evolved into a unique and focused time of leadership development. Since 1993, NM has hosted its Summer Internship as a way to invest in a select team of emerging leaders while also bringing in fresh energy to pull off some of the biggest events of the year. Every summer, a group of competitively selected high school students join other college students and young adults in theological training, targeted leadership development, and lots of hard work to execute the summer ministry activities.  

2012 Summer Intern Team

 

This summer we have the strongest class of summer intern applicants to date, and so, we have expanded our numbers to 17 Emerging Leaders - our largest team ever. Because our team has grown, we are in need of extra funds to help pay the summer stipend for these 17 young leaders. Each emerging leader receives $1,500 for their hard work over the 10 weeks of our summer. That means we need $25,500 total to pay all of our young leaders this summer. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

We have a few donors already giving towards our summer internship, but we still need an additional $12,000 from this campaign to cover all the intern stipends. All profits above our hard costs from this Indiegogo campaign are designated to the 2013 summer intern stipend.

To help us raise these funds for our emerging leaders, we have a number of perks to offer to you. First, our NM Media team will be documenting the activity of our interns with photographs and video footage. All of this media will be compiled into a documentary at the end of the summer - to showcase the work of our youth. Anyone who donates at least $5 will receive an email link to view this video upon completion. 

 

Second, for a $12 donation, we will send you a Neighborhood Ministries branded USB drive bracelet and the video link above. The USB drive has a 4 GB capacity. 

 

Third, for a $20 donation, we will send you a copy of our coffee-table book, The Relentless Pursuit: Stories of God's Hope, Love and Grace in the Neighborhood. This book is full of 200 pages of pictures and stories that illustrate the formation of the ministry and communicate the lessons learned along the way. 


 

Fourth, for $30, we will send you a special edition t-shirt, made specifically for this Indiegogo campaign. The shirts are printed by Opportunitees, our on-site screenprinting and embroidery business, on a lightweight and comfortable, 100% ring-spun cotton, V-neck t-shirt. Sizes offered are XS-2XL in a unisex cut. Featured on the back of the shirt is this quote from author and artist Ralph Ransom: 

Before the reward there must be labor. You plant before you harvest. You sow in tears before you reap in joy.

 


Fifth, for $55, we will send you a short-sleeve, three-button, golf polo. The polo features Reebok's lightweight PLAYDRY material and has Neighoborhood Ministries' logo embroidered on the sleeve. This shirt is also produced at Opportunitees and comes in Men's sizes S-3XL. 

photo coming soon

 

Lastly, for $75, we will send you a high-quality print on 11x17" paper of Kyle Matthews' (NM two year intern) original artwork featured on our special edition summer intern tee. Each print will be individually signed and numbered by Kyle. Limited run of 25 prints. 

 

The Impact

Collectively, our internship team will log well over 15,000 hours developing as leaders and working for the betterment of our community. They will play a vital role in executing a two week day camp which will host over 700 children and several hundred volunteers on our campus. Also, they will take a group of seventy 5th-7th graders up to a week long camp in northern Arizona. They will work the gardens of Hope House Farms; they will knock on over 1,000 doors of community houses - listening to the needs of our neighbors. They will work in the bike shop to foster micro-enterprise development, and assemble and deliver 50 kits that teach families with young children to foster brain development at home. 

Most importantly, they will take one giant step further in believing God will use them as the agents of change that our community needs to grow stronger. 

 

 

Besides making a contribution, we'd love it if you would:

  • Share our campaign on facebook, twitter or G+
  • And tell your friends about what we are doing.

Also, they will take a group of seventy 5th-7th graders up to a week long camp in northern Arizona. They will work the gardens of Hope House Farms; they will knock on over 1,000 doors of community houses - listening to the needs of our neighbors. They will work in the bike shop to foster micro-enterprise development, and assemble and deliver 50 kits that teach families with young children to foster brain development at home. 
Most importantly, they will take one giant step further in believing God will use them as the agents of change that our community needs to grow stronger. 
 
 


Besides making a contribution, we'd love it if you would:

Share our campaign on facebook, twitter or G+
And tell your friends about what we are doing.

story:
Kaima - Organic Farm for Youth-at-Risk

What is the need and how can it be creatively addressed?

In today's world, teens often find it difficult to relate to conventional social values; consequently, they withdraw from society, drop out of school and slip into isolation.

At Kaima Organic Farm, we have created an innovative solution to this problem by creating a unique outdoor space where drop-out teens will gain employability skills, work experience, leadership development and community building skills and enjoy the benefits of teamwork. The teens will see themselves as fully invested partners in this undertaking, as they will receive a salary for working on the farm.

What is Kaima?

Kaima, (sustainability in Aramaic), is a newly established Israeli NGO that will re-engage, motivate and empower drop-out, at-risk youth who cannot adjust to, let alone thrive in, other social settings. Teens on our program will gain agricultural and leadership skills, learn communication and marketing, basic business knowledge, fiscal and personal accountability, and environmental responsibility. They will learn how to achieve environmental sustainability by growing their own food, collecting rainwater and restoring diminished landscapes and ecosystems.

Where is Kaima?

The project is on 12 dunams (3 acres) of fertile land in the village of Moshav Beit Zayit - donated by generous local families.

Who are our partners?

In collaboration with other NGO's and government authorities, we are committed to transforming the lives of a distressing number of youth who have exceptional difficulty finding their place in the world and are living on the margins of society.

Who is eligible?

Youth-at-risk (as identified by the Ministry of Education) who have either fallen out of the system or are receiving minimal formal instruction. Candidates will undergo a competitive interview process to be selected for inclusion in this project.

What's the plan?

The first crops will be planted by Kaima's board, members of the community and other volunteers. Once up and running, activities will take place daily in shifts from 8:00 - 4:00.

What does our pedagogic model have the power to do?

  • Legitimize non-conventional educational settings.
  • Encourage young people to engage in positive interaction with adults and their peers.
  • Provide on-the-job training and life skills for marginalized youth
  • Give urban youth the opportunity to engage with nature.

The Kaima Organic Farm offers a real chance to contribute to a society in which a growing number of kids feel no sense of personal pride or civic responsibility. This grassroots initiative has the ambition and and potential to become a model for replication in other communities.

Founders:

Yoni Yefet Raich

Nadav Ben Susan

Ishai Revkin Fenton

Noa Fein & Michael Mizrahi

Nomi Lifshitz

Uri Kandel

Erez Shpivak 

Aviva Feferman 

Tamir Deutch 

Eli Levi 

Sharon Ya'acovan 

Nehama Perel 

Erez Nota 

CONTACT INFORMATION

Contact:

Yoni Yefet Reich 

Phone:

972-52-381-7793

Email:

kaima.office@gmail.com

Address:

Beit Zayit 42, 90815 Israel

Amuta Registration:

580568103

 

 Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/Kaima.BeitZait

Youtube: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wqIjz87mWcM

story:
Hello, we are Sally and Rachel, 'MIT Sisters'.

We "jumped off the cliff, and are building our wings on the way down": we need to pay back all the money that we have borrowed to make it over to the USA to become official MIT-accredited teachers of "New Ventures Leadership". 

Please help us!  We will be teaching others and paying forward our treasured MIT learnings and experience through our numerous future community-building and entrepreneurial-education programmes.
Find out more about us by watching this video: 


We are from opposite sides of the world (Sally is from Brisbane, Australia and Rachel is from Rome, Italy) and fate brought us together in a collision of energy, hopes and dreams: the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) became our unexpected connective tissue, and the Internet our glue. Six months ago we didn’t know each other. We now chat on Skype two to three times a week and are each other’s rock-solid sounding board. Together we cheer each other onwards in pursuing the multifaceted challenges that make up our lives in the domains of entrepreneurship, learning, and motherhood. We are both happily married, and have 7 children between the 2 of us. We are always looking for that very delicate balance between living out our life purpose and dreams, and not forsaking our responsibilities.

 
Sally Coldrick is a corporate intrapreneur turned entrepreneur. Previously a marketing strategist at Accenture, she is an Alumna of the MIT Global Entrepreneurship Bootcamp in South Korea. Sally established her business [Up & Grow] in 2015 to help entrepreneurs create and build sustainable businesses but has had it on hold this year to invest time in learning as much as possible about entrepreneurship herself!  She holds a Bachelor of Commerce and is a strategic thinking ‘do-er’. 

Rachel Hentsch is a startupper who since over 2 years has been working on  useit, an Italian Sharing Economy platform. Rachel holds a BA in Architecture, from University of Cambridge and Università La Sapienza, and was a practicing Architect for several years before becoming passionate about designing experiences to enable sharing through technology. She is an MIT Global Entrepreneurship Bootcamper, Hive Global Leader, and Huffpost Contributor. Rachel is married since 1992 and has 5 children.


Rachel and Sally, with their respective Families

After successfully completing the MIT Global Entrepreneurship Bootcamp in Seoul (South Korea) last March, we both applied and were accepted into MIT’s Disciplined Entrepreneurship Bootcamp Teacher Training (2 in 20 people selected from around the world), at the MIT in Cambridge, Massachusetts. Our training will start on the 7th of August 2016.  You can read more about our Bootcamp adventures here on our #MITsisters Medium Channel

We were so thrilled at such a once-in-a lifetime-opportunity that we decided to take the leap-- and sort out the rest afterwards: and so, here we are! 

NO, we have NOT got it all sorted out... yet.

And YES, we have basically bitten off more than we can chew!
But we have great faith in the power of daring.
Ours is a case of having jumped off the cliff, and of building our wings on the way down: we are currently flying high on short term, high-interest credit to make it to the MIT Bootcamp. But we will need to pay back all the money that we have borrowed to make it over to the USA. So we REALLY need your help! But there is something in this for EACH of you.

Our aim at MITSisters is to share the precious learnings acquired at MIT and the teachings of the Disciplined Entrepreneurship framework to individuals around the world through our ‪#‎MITBootcampFrontiers‬ articles, featuring the ups and downs of entrepreneurship. Real stories from entrepreneurs from around the world that will help you learn from the successes and failures of others.

Entrepreneurship can be taught, and by the end of August we will be equipped with the necessary tools (and will be MIT-accredited!!!) to help spread this knowledge to contribute to a more healthy entrepreneurial system. This is where we ask for your help!


What We Need & What You Get for Helping us!

We are aiming to raise a total of $7,000 to cover our travel, accommodation and "brain fuel" expenses, which is broken down as follows:

  • $2,900 for 2 weeks of shared accommodation at the Boston Hostel
  • $1,500 for Sally's flights from Brisbane to Boston and back home
  • $1,150 for Rachel's flights from Rome to Boston and back home
  • $1,450 for food and local transportation (about $52 each, per day).
In return, you will be able to choose from a whole range of creative, unique and exclusive perks through which we will be sharing our MIT experience and learnings: from specially dedicated photos, to webinar tickets, to being mentioned in our press articles (see the perks section for full details). There IS something in this for EACH of you, even if it is just keeping you entertained for the next few weeks!

Anything raised above and beyond will be used to help the MIT sisters grow their entrepreneurial story-telling reach and impact more people’s lives.

WIIFM- "What's In It For Me?"
You help us, we help you! 

Many of our PERKS have been designed to be valuable for people who want to know whether entrepreneurship is for them and if so, to guide them through the first steps they need to take to become successful. Knowing where to start is often the hardest part. The program takes out the guess work and SHOWS you where to start, using the PROVEN framework developed by MIT. 

What niggling problems could our PERKS answer for you? 

  • Is entrepreneurship for you? 
  • Have you started a business but are currently stagnant? People don’t know where to start, they need structure to follow, they have limited time and resources available to invest. 
  • If you have already got a business, can you define what problem you are solving and who you are solving it for?

Even if Entrepreneurship is not your focus, we would still love to share with you the thrills of our special MIT experience, so our other PERKS are designed to share with you peeps and insights into our time in the amazing MIT community: because by expressing your support you will become a very cherished and important part of our Mission Impossible! 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some of you may just wish to help but not in a position to donate yourself. We would be so grateful for you to pay this forward and share it with other's in your network who may be interested in entrepreneurship, or in lending a helping hand to two tenacious women.

We THANK YOU IN ADVANCE 
for anything you are willing and able to do to help and support us on our challenging but exciting journey.


We would be most happy if you would like to share feedback, make requests, and ask questions. We value your input and would love to incorporate you ideas where possible. Please feel free to contact us by writing to mitsisters [at] gmail.com

story:
A massive thank you to everyone who supported our crowdfunding campaign enabling us to reach our goal and beyond!  Thanks to you, we will be starting the project in February 2017 by sand blasting of the beams and ceiling to remove peeling paint. 
It is not too late if you still want to donate!  Please visit our website page: http://www.butserancientfarm.co.uk/villa-renova...  where you will find a donation button.

Butser Ancient Farm is a gem in the crown of the South Downs National Park in Hampshire, UK. Our beautiful villa has been worn down by the thousands of people visiting the farm each year, who come to learn how the Romans lived in Britain nearly 2,000 years ago.

Whether you visited Butser Ancient Farm as a child, are a Friend of Butser and supporter, or have never visited but like the look of our site, please consider making a donation today to bring our villa up to the standard a wealthy Roman would expect.

Where else in the world can you experience a Roman villa inside and out as it actually would have looked and felt to our ancestors?

The Need

As you can see in the video, the paint is peeling from the beams of the villa and the earth packed floors could be so beautiful if laid with mosaics and herringbone tiles.

The visitor experience at Butser Ancient Farm is unique as people step back in time through reconstructed Stone Age, Iron Age, Roman and Saxon houses, learning how our ancestors lived and adapted to their environment.

However, you can see the Roman house has become a little shabby and in need of attention. Its refurbishment will pave the way for other projects which will vastly improve the whole Roman area at Butser, including mosaic floors and a Roman garden.

The Goal

£2,000 will pay for sandblasting the beams to enhance the wood and get rid of the flaky paint.  This will take place in February half term 2017 when there will be no school visits and fewer public on site and will launch the whole renovation project.

The cost of all the renovation work is £100,000 but it is the beams that need to be cleaned up first. 

The next stage of renovation will start at the end of May 2017 with the aim to complete by September 2017 ready for a grand opening, followed by our busiest school season of the year.

Our Track Record

Butser Ancient Farm is a centre of educational excellence known as being the birthplace of experimental archaeology in Britain and a leading example for other research centres across the world.  The site has gone from strength to strength.  Our Saxon house is a finalist in the Hampshire Countryside Sustainable Buildings Award and with your help we can bring the Roman villa up to a similar standard of excellence!

How you can help

Whether or not you are able to donate, please spread the word! Send this link to all your friends and acquaintances and share our project on Facebook, Twitter and even in your local newsletter or noticeboard – that would help us so much!

Thank you from the Butser Team!

story:
1. Our Team

The three team members, Rukmani Mohindra from India, Akiko Takahashi from Japan and Christian W. Atzfrom Germany with a common thought of seeing happy people came to work together for makehappy.in.


     

2. What is Makehappy?

We are running a website, "makehappy.in" which bridges the daily online shopping and the chance to support a NGO achieving good causes in India.  With makehappy users can add a good meaning to their daily online purchases.

      makehappy.in http://makehappy.in/

  


How it works

  1. Search for your favorite shop from our list & click the logo to get redirected to the website.. We have partner shops in various categories Travel, Fashion, Flowers and others.
  2. Shop as usual. The shop gives us commission money according to your purchase.
  3. Part of the commission money is given to a NGO/NPO we select with you.



We forward 70% of the commission to a good cause (currently: Music Basti based in Delhi), the other 30% pay our expenses.

How do we get commission : we get some percentage of user’s purchase as commission money from our partner shop whenever user shops via makehappy.

Future Plans:- Makehappy 2.0

We are now preparing for what we call "makehappy 2.0". For the next release we will add features, such as “login“ and a virtual "contribution account", so you can follow up the amount that has been forwarded by you. We also want to partner with 10-15 NGOs and let you select the cause that gets supported with the affiliate commission that comes in because of you.

3. Our expectations 

We need your support to host a work camp in Europe and to set up our company in India.

We developed and released the current version of makehappy during iAccelerator programin India together.



After that, we are working for makehappy from remote site. As the productive and inspiring working experience was unforgettable, we want to get together to work as a team to implement above mentioned makehappy 2.0 and release it together afterwards.

Chris and Akiko are based in Germany and Austria, Rukmani is in India. We decided to get together in Black Forest (Germany) and Upper Austria, as it will be a great experience to meet in Europe, after we worked together in India in December and January. The workcamp will last 2 weeks, one week in Germany and one week in Austria.

We want to raise money to pay the travel expenses for Rukmani and the setup of the company in India.

Following costs we have calculated:
  • Visa application: $100
  • Airline ticket: $700
  • Transportation expenses within Germany: $200
  • Company setup in India (official fees, legal advise, initial capital): $1500
 

4. What we do in return for your support

To express our happiness and gratefulness we made a list of versatile perks, which you can see on the right side.

5. Other ways you can help and support

Spread the word! We are super thankful when you share this campaign and our makehappy project everywhere online and offline. Simply post it on your blog, on your own or your friends facebook site, send out a tweet, get a tattoo with our logo or paint it on your own house wall... Be creative! The more people know about makehappy, the bigger impact it will have.

We are also glad to receive your feedback, ideas and suggestions. Tell us which online shops you usually shop at and we will check if we can partner with them. Also, tell us about your favorite NGOs in India, as we are looking forward to support good causes and trustworthy NGOs. When you live in India, please use makehappy for your online purchases and help us making the world 10 times happier.

More information

Our web pages:

  • http://www.makehppy.in
  • http://www.facebook.com/makehappy.in
  • https://twitter.com/makehappy_in

Media coverages:

  • MakeHappy.in: Germany based Christian W. Atz merges E-commerce with Social Entrepreneurship on Yourstory.in
  • Makehappy Gives Indian E-Commerce a Charitable Twist on Tech in Asia
  • Starting Up: iAccelerator 2012 at IIM-Ahmedabad on The Economic Times



< end >



------- our initial plan (we leave this to keep our activity transparent) -------

previous video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=g587RSxlvW8&context=C4d2b83cADvjVQa1PpcFO4dgUo_ZZ_YZYjHZC7vMFBhKND-yoBnXQ=

Our Story

Imagine: You enter a shop, then you go to the salesperson and say:

"Hey, I want to buy a certain product at your place. But I know, that I could actually buy it somewhere else. So lets make a deal. I buy it at your place and you give a certain percentage of the money I spend on it to an NGO that supports a cause, I care about".
And the salesperson answers:
"alright, deal!"
Does it sound too idealistic? Maybe. But it works. Somehow. Especially in the internet. It's makehappy.in!


makehappy.in

Online shops and services are hungry for every customer. So they give a commission to partner website, that make advertisement for the online shop and link potential customers onto their website. Affiliate Marketing.

We believe that affiliate commission should be used to support good and charitable causes.
And to make it easy for you and other users to generate affiliate commissions to support good causes, we want to setup a webportal, embed as many online shops as possible, that grant a certain commission for successful leads and sales.

So, every time you intend to shop online, you can visit our website, click the logo of your favorite shop to get redirected to it.

Shopping is done as usual and price stays exactly the same price. Just for clicking the logo we receive a commission, well you have to buy a product and service too ;). 70% of the commission we forward to the cause, you care most about. You can select which one out of 10-15. The other 30% are used to cover our costs and to spread the word.

You can also have a virtual account and track your contributions to NGOs or tie up with your friends to contribute as a group and have greater impact.
We love India and we want to support the NGOs in India, so we plan to setup makehappy for India initially and then launch it in other countries.

The Impact

We have attented IAccelerator, an incubation program from IIM-Ahmedabad and setup a first version of the above mentioned web portal during our stay.
This first version of makehappy features more than 40 online shops, commissions are between 0.75% and 20% of the purchase value. Average is 6%, commissions for booking of domestic airline tickets are around Rs. 200.

With more than 100mio internet users in India, 10mio online shoppers and more than 10bn US$ revenue in e-commerce the impact of our service will be great. An average online shopper spends 1000 US$ annually for products, services and airline tickets. We estimate that at least 60% will be bought via our partner shops, this makes 600 US$.

600 US$ generate 36 US$ in commissions (6% average). So when 70% of this amount are forwarded, more than 25 US$ go to a charitable cause. 25 US$ from each average user each user.
Wow. That is a lot of money and when thousands of user shop via makehappy the impact will be noticeable and big.

We assume that at least 60% will be bought via our partner shops, this makes 600 US$.
600 US$ generate 36 US$ in commissions (6% average). So when 70% of this amount are forwarded, more than 25 US$ go to a charitable cause.
25 US$ from each average user each user. Wow :)
A lot of money and when thousands of user shop via makehappy the impact will be noticeable and big.

What We Need & What You Get

We want to get together and host a 20 day work camp in April to concentrate on makehappy and to grow as a team to come up with the best ideas for the website and to spread the word about our project in the best way.
We also need to setup a company in India. And but not least we would like to invite a coder to support our project.

So the money is needed for:

  • Airline tickets: $1000.-
  • Apartment rental: $500.-
  • Company setup: $500.-
  • Developer: $500.-

 

To express our happy- and gratefulness we made a list of versatile perks, which you can see on the right side.

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word! We are super thankful when you share this campaign and our makehappy project everywhere online and offline. Simply post it on your blog, on your own or your friends facebook site, send out a tweet, get a tattoo with our logo or paint it on your own house wall... Be creative! The more people know about makehappy, the bigger impact it will have. We are also glad to receive your feedback, ideas and suggestions. Tell us which online shops you usually shop at and we will check if we can partner with them. Also, tell us about your favorite NGOs in India, as we are looking for trustworthy and good doing ones. When you live in India, please use makehappy before you do your online purchases.



Thank you very much!

your makehappy-Team
story_txt:
1. Our Team
The three team members, Rukmani Mohindra from India, Akiko Takahashi from Japan and Christian W. Atzfrom Germany with a common thought of seeing happy people came to work together for makehappy.in.

     2. What is Makehappy?
We are running a website, "makehappy.in" which bridges the daily online shopping and the chance to support a NGO achieving good causes in India.  With makehappy users can add a good meaning to their daily online purchases.      makehappy.in http://makehappy.in/

   

How it works

Search for your favorite shop from our list & click the logo to get redirected to the website.. We have partner shops in various categories Travel, Fashion, Flowers and others.
Shop as usual. The shop gives us commission money according to your purchase.
Part of the commission money is given to a NGO/NPO we select with you.

We forward 70% of the commission to a good cause (currently: Music Basti based in Delhi), the other 30% pay our expenses.How do we get commission : we get some percentage of user’s purchase as commission money from our partner shop whenever user shops via makehappy.Future Plans:- Makehappy 2.0
We are now preparing for what we call "makehappy 2.0". For the next release we will add features, such as “login“ and a virtual "contribution account", so you can follow up the amount that has been forwarded by you. We also want to partner with 10-15 NGOs and let you select the cause that gets supported with the affiliate commission that comes in because of you.3. Our expectations 
We need your support to host a work camp in Europe and to set up our company in India.
We developed and released the current version of makehappy during iAccelerator programin India together.

After that, we are working for makehappy from remote site. As the productive and inspiring working experience was unforgettable, we want to get together to work as a team to implement above mentioned makehappy 2.0 and release it together afterwards.Chris and Akiko are based in Germany and Austria, Rukmani is in India. We decided to get together in Black Forest (Germany) and Upper Austria, as it will be a great experience to meet in Europe, after we worked together in India in December and January. The workcamp will last 2 weeks, one week in Germany and one week in Austria.We want to raise money to pay the travel expenses for Rukmani and the setup of the company in India.Following costs we have calculated:
Visa application: $100
Airline ticket: $700
Transportation expenses within Germany: $200
Company setup in India (official fees, legal advise, initial capital): $1500

 4. What we do in return for your support
To express our happiness and gratefulness we made a list of versatile perks, which you can see on the right side.5. Other ways you can help and support
Spread the word! We are super thankful when you share this campaign and our makehappy project everywhere online and offline. Simply post it on your blog, on your own or your friends facebook site, send out a tweet, get a tattoo with our logo or paint it on your own house wall... Be creative! The more people know about makehappy, the bigger impact it will have.We are also glad to receive your feedback, ideas and suggestions. Tell us which online shops you usually shop at and we will check if we can partner with them. Also, tell us about your favorite NGOs in India, as we are looking forward to support good causes and trustworthy NGOs. When you live in India, please use makehappy for your online purchases and help us making the world 10 times happier.More information
Our web pages:

http://www.makehppy.in
http://www.facebook.com/makehappy.in
https://twitter.com/makehappy_in

Media coverages:


MakeHappy.in: Germany based Christian W. Atz merges E-commerce with Social Entrepreneurship on Yourstory.in

Makehappy Gives Indian E-Commerce a Charitable Twist on Tech in Asia

Starting Up: iAccelerator 2012 at IIM-Ahmedabad on The Economic Times

< end >------- our initial plan (we leave this to keep our activity transparent) -------previous video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=g587RSxlvW8&context=C4d2b83cADvjVQa1PpcFO4dgUo_ZZ_YZYjHZC7vMFBhKND-yoBnXQ=
Our Story
Imagine: You enter a shop, then you go to the salesperson and say:
"Hey, I want to buy a certain product at your place. But I know, that I could actually buy it somewhere else. So lets make a deal. I buy it at your place and you give a certain percentage of the money I spend on it to an NGO that supports a cause, I care about".
And the salesperson answers:
"alright, deal!"
Does it sound too idealistic? Maybe. But it works. Somehow. Especially in the internet. It's makehappy.in! 
makehappy.in

Online shops and services are hungry for every customer. So they give a commission to partner website, that make advertisement for the online shop and link potential customers onto their website. Affiliate Marketing.
We believe that affiliate commission should be used to support good and charitable causes.
And to make it easy for you and other users to generate affiliate commissions to support good causes, we want to setup a webportal, embed as many online shops as possible, that grant a certain commission for successful leads and sales.
So, every time you intend to shop online, you can visit our website, click the logo of your favorite shop to get redirected to it.
Shopping is done as usual and price stays exactly the same price. Just for clicking the logo we receive a commission, well you have to buy a product and service too ;). 70% of the commission we forward to the cause, you care most about. You can select which one out of 10-15. The other 30% are used to cover our costs and to spread the word. 
You can also have a virtual account and track your contributions to NGOs or tie up with your friends to contribute as a group and have greater impact. We love India and we want to support the NGOs in India, so we plan to setup makehappy for India initially and then launch it in other countries.
The Impact
We have attented IAccelerator, an incubation program from IIM-Ahmedabad and setup a first version of the above mentioned web portal during our stay. This first version of makehappy features more than 40 online shops, commissions are between 0.75% and 20% of the purchase value. Average is 6%, commissions for booking of domestic airline tickets are around Rs. 200.
With more than 100mio internet users in India, 10mio online shoppers and more than 10bn US$ revenue in e-commerce the impact of our service will be great. An average online shopper spends 1000 US$ annually for products, services and airline tickets. We estimate that at least 60% will be bought via our partner shops, this makes 600 US$.
600 US$ generate 36 US$ in commissions (6% average). So when 70% of this amount are forwarded, more than 25 US$ go to a charitable cause. 25 US$ from each average user each user.  Wow. That is a lot of money and when thousands of user shop via makehappy the impact will be noticeable and big.
We assume that at least 60% will be bought via our partner shops, this makes 600 US$. 600 US$ generate 36 US$ in commissions (6% average). So when 70% of this amount are forwarded, more than 25 US$ go to a charitable cause. 25 US$ from each average user each user. Wow :) A lot of money and when thousands of user shop via makehappy the impact will be noticeable and big.
What We Need & What You Get
We want to get together and host a 20 day work camp in April to concentrate on makehappy and to grow as a team to come up with the best ideas for the website and to spread the word about our project in the best way. We also need to setup a company in India. And but not least we would like to invite a coder to support our project.
So the money is needed for:

Airline tickets: $1000.-
Apartment rental: $500.-
Company setup: $500.-
Developer: $500.-

 
To express our happy- and gratefulness we made a list of versatile perks, which you can see on the right side.
Other Ways You Can Help
Spread the word! We are super thankful when you share this campaign and our makehappy project everywhere online and offline. Simply post it on your blog, on your own or your friends facebook site, send out a tweet, get a tattoo with our logo or paint it on your own house wall... Be creative! The more people know about makehappy, the bigger impact it will have. We are also glad to receive your feedback, ideas and suggestions. Tell us which online shops you usually shop at and we will check if we can partner with them. Also, tell us about your favorite NGOs in India, as we are looking for trustworthy and good doing ones. When you live in India, please use makehappy before you do your online purchases.
Thank you very much! your makehappy-Team

story:
About Suzanne:

Suzanne was a kind, supportive, responsible, funny and loving young woman who passed away suddenly over the summer of 2011 during a research trip she was conducting with the University of Alberta. She was highly involved in the local Edmonton choral scene, and made an incredible impact on those who she met and sang with. She was also deeply dedicated to education, nature, and biology, holding an Undergraduate and Masters degree in science from the University of Alberta.


"On August 18, 2011 Suzanne Elizabeth Abele died as she lived - responsibly carrying out
the ordinary tasks of life in an extraordinary way. Her departure from this life was sudden, and the end of her earthly existence is deeply felt by her family, friends, colleagues and nature itself."


The Impact

Your monetary donation will help the Alberta Choral Federation create a scholarship in the name of Suzanne to help students who are currently studying in science, but are highly involved in local choirs. We are aiming to raise an initial $10 000 for the scholarship, so that it can be awarded over numerous years.

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word! Send this initiative to anyone who knew, studied, sang and loved Suzanne. Any and all monetary amounts are welcome, be it $5 or $500. Thank you in advance for your love and support.

story:
Who we are:

Samuel Lang

     Ex-military and law enforcement. I served in the armed forces prior to receiving an honorable medical separation for a tumor obtained while on duty status.

     Since then I have developed a passion for martial arts, grappling and Brazillian Jiu Jitsu specifically. I am very active in the community and have a loving, supportive family.

Shayne Yetter

     Avid Brazillian Jiu Jitsu practictioner. I have been studying the art for about a year and am seeking a place where my work and school schedule will allow me to stay active.

Austin Hanzlik

     Currently enlisted in the United States Air Force. I am new to grappling and MMA outside of what I have trained in the military but am excited to have a place to practice. I have a family of four and a full work schedule so I'm very excited about the prospect of an all-hours location to stay in shape.

 

What we're doing:

     We are looking to expand upon what we have deleloped as a free grappling gym in Nampa, Idaho. We want provide a safe, non-threatening atmosphere for those that are looking to get fit, learn some self-defense or to improve their lives through the disciplines that are taught in martial arts.

 

     At the Nampa No-Gi school we teach kids to be confident and respectful as well as promoting a team atmosphere for them to enjoy. We instill self-respect and anti-bullying while providing a fun, free way to exercise.

 

     We live in a very low income area and many people can't afford high-cost gyms (which most that offer grappling are). Aside from that many of us operate on very different schedules and this is a way for the members to pick times in which everyone can attend classes.

     Some of the classes include, but are not limited to:

    • Wrestling     
    • Brazillian Jiu Jitsu
    • Muay Thai
    • Boxing
    • Strength Training 

     Everything that we offer are at no cost to the members and are supported by volunteer staff. We have personal connections in all of the disciplines listed above as well as active wrestlers, grapplers and mixed martial artists that are willing to provide free training. Once operations are more managable we plan to make guest trainers a weekly occurence.                       

    

What We Need:

We need help with the supply cost, all work and maintenance is on us!:

 

  • We already have a foundation down and mats that will work for now. We also have wall supports surrounding the grappling area. What we do need is more wall padding to make grappling more safe. So far we have about 30% of the area covered. The rest we can do, by hand using soft foam and non-abrasive covers. We can achieve this with about $200.   COST: $200

 

 

  • Our facility is without any central heating or air conditioning. We have a small heating unit that doesn't quite do as much as we need it to during the winter evenings. We hope to get better heating and cooling control that will make cold and hot seasons more bearable for training.    COST: $250

 

  • Lastly, and perhaps most importantly we want to apply for non-profit status in the State of Idaho. In order to do so we need to file for tax exempt status and the going rate to submit the paperwork is a little bit expensive. If the campaign does well we will be applying for tax exempt status through the 501(c)(3) process.    COST: $800

     

  • The final set of items that we are looking to buy are more optional and miscellaneous. If we are able to we will be buying extra gloves, wraps, mouth guards and rash guards for those that come to the Nampa No-Gi School.    COST: APP. $250

 

 

                                    TOTAL NEED: $1500

 

  • Anything extra will go to little things that we, at NNG could use. This can include team t-shirts, extra water, weight training supplies and grappling / striking bags.

 

The Impact:

We provide free access for kids and adults to a friendly training atmosphere

  • Martial arts is a great tool for teaching children discipline, self-respect and confidence
  • Gives people means for self defense
  • Fantastic way to meet people, socialize, and bring together the community
  • Allows people with very little means to have a place to train
  • Promotes a team atmosphere for kids that might be under social pressure in their environments
  • Teaches anti-bullying and promotes civility and respect

No Money? No Problem:

Word of mouth goes a long way

  • If you feel strongly about what we are trying to do but don’t have the means to help financially please pass on our campaign to a friend
  • Even on this page, there's a multitude of sharing options. Social networking and a passing word can be the difference between failure and the success of our dream!

Thank you for your time. I know this was a lot to read and, regardless of whether or not you decide to donate- we appreciate it!

If you feel the need, don't hesitate to contact us with any questions.

Samuel Lang: samuelmaxlang@gmail.com

Shayne Yetter: yetter.shayne@gmail.com

Austin Hanzlik: austin.hanzlik@facebook.com

 

Follow us, keep an eye on what we're doing!

Twitter: @MovementMMA

Youtube: http://www.youtube.com/user/MovementMMA

Blogger: http://nampanogi.blogspot.com/

 

Have a great day and thank you, again.

story:
Dizzy’s Bus Stop will be hosting its 4th Annual Carnival on Sunday, August 25th from 12pm - 4pm! Our annual carnival is great for families and the community to celebrate the end of summer with lots of games, bouncy houses, train rides, pony rides, face painting, Dizzy's Tumblebus, and much more! Proceeds help support our scholarship program which provides tuition for families who do not have the financial means to pay for our programs. We believe all children should have the opportunity to participate in Dizzy's Tumblebus weekly classes or play and learn at Dizzy's Bus Stop. This year we are reaching out to our awesome Dizzy's Tumblebus families, friends, and local businesses to help raise money so we can continue providing scholarships for our programs.

If you would like to help us reach our goal of $3,000 for our annual carnival we have some great perks for families and businesses. Check them out!

story:
BEAM INC. 

My name is Posiola Susan, and I'm BEAM Inc.'s Secretary - BEAM stands for Bringing Educational Assistance to Many Inc. As a director at BEAM Inc. I am raising some funds to support this year's project. 

#Fun Facts

  • BEAM Inc. was established April 2008.
  • BEAM Inc. is a registered not-for-profit organization in Ontario.
  • Our mission is to provide educational assistance to underprivileged children in Nigeria’s public school system. 
  • 100% of the funds we generate is used in providing supplies for the students.
  • Find out more here

#Past Delivery 

  1. Dec. 2008: Salvation Army Primary School - Lagos State, Nigeria - 300 Students
  2. Dec. 2009: Akaboezem Primary School - Anambra State, Nigeria - 300 Students 
  3. Dec. 2010: Ogale State School - Rivers States, Nigeria - 600 Students 
  4. Dec. 2011: St. James Primary School - Ondo State, Nigeria - 640 Students
  5. Jan. 2013: Community Primary School (CPS) Ajouna CPS Amugu / Umuorua & CPS Obukpa - Enugu State, Nigeria - 700 Students*

*We rebuilt the school 

#How you can Help

  • Support my campaign and help me raise $1200.
  • Follow us on Twitter, like us on Facebook. 
  • Spread the words among your friends
  • Help "Educate" a child.

My idea of education is to unsettle the minds of the young and inflame their intellects.  ~Robert Maynard Hutchins

story:
Who We Are:

We are a group of pre-service teachers from the Education program at the University of Prince Edward Island.  There are twenty-six of us specializing in International and Indigenous Education.  We will all be completing a six-week teaching placement during March and April 2013 in an international setting.  This experience will not only be transformational for each of us on a personal level from living and teaching in a culture that differs from our own, but we will return as a group with a great wealth of knowledge to bring into our future classrooms, whether on PEI or elsewhere.  The countries we will be traveling to in the Spring include China, France, New Zealand, Sweden, and Togo.

This international experience, however, will be an expensive venture for each of us as we are responsible for covering our own travel and living costs.  Plane tickets, living accomodations, and other expenses for this six-week placement will be impossible to meet without extensive fundraising - which we started in May 2012.  Depending on the location of our placement, we will each be expected to contribute $3,000 - $4,000, in addition to our university tuition costs.  We will not receive any compensation while engaged in this teaching practice.

It is for this reason that we are asking for any assistance you can provide.  No matter the size of your donation, it will be greatly appreciated and recognized by us, as well as the entire Faculty of Education.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate online, or wish to take a different approach, here are some other ways that you can help us:

  • Share our Indie-Go-Go campaign with your friends and family.
  • Attend one of our many events happening around Charlottetown, PEI.
  • Get the word out about our group any way you can.

A portion of the proceeds will be dontated to an educational charity.

All help will be very much appreciated!

story:
Our Story

I am Jessica, mama to Allyson Justice, 4 years old. As a single mother raising a bi-cultural child one of the most important values I strive to instill in Allyson is a strong connection between her and her Latina heritage. One strategy I have used to nuture this connection is exposing Allyson to the Spanish language.  Over the last four years Allyson has been exposed to Spanish speaking caregivers, Spanish lessons, and my attemps to read the plethora of Spanish books we own. As Allyson's language capabilities have expanded, I have realized that she needs more than I, or a weekly Spanish class, can offer.  My search to find a viable option to continue to nurture Allyson's Spanish development has lead me to summer Spanish immersion day camps. I have found a program that will work with our needs and schedule, but the $2200 in tuition (while competitive with similar programs) will not fit into my modest student budget.

My hope is that with your support I can make this experience a reality for my daughter without having to place myself in debt to do so.  Your generosity will be met with my deepest grattitute in addition to an original piece of art created by the one, and only, Allyson Justice.

Thank you in advance for your support!

Jessica

If you would like to research the program Allyson will be atteding more information can be found at http://www.trlanguages.com/Summer_program.aspx.
