story:
Hi, I'm Frank Santoro. I'm going to open an awesome schoolhouse residency for comic book making and I need your help.

==============================================

HELLO!!! IF YOU HAVE NOT RECEIVED YOUR PERK -- WE ARE WORKING ON IT!!! WE HAVE CONTACTED EVERYONE WE THINK - HOWEVER IF WE MISSED YOU Please email santoroschoolATgmailDOTcom with any questions. THANKS FOR YOUR PATIENCE!!!

CHECK OUT OUR NEW WEBSITE

and check out this report on our first residents
http://comicsworkbook.com/rowhouse-residency-report/

follow us on instagram @comicsworkbook and @rowhouseresidency and @santoro.frank

THE ROWHOUSE RESIDENCY IS OPEN AND TAKING APPLICATIONS

please email santoroschool@gmail.com

======================

Who the hell am I, anyways? I've been making and writing about comics since 1988. My work has been exhibited at the American Academy of Arts and Letters in New York and the Carnegie Museum in Pittsburgh. Allegedly, I'm a good egg and one of the most passionate proselytizers for comic books and visual literacy that you will ever meet.

I'm from Pittsburgh, PA and I want to make this city the best place in the world to learn comic book making. Beyond that and closer to home I want to improve the neighborhood I am from. I grew up in this neighborhood in Pittsburgh called Swissvale---and my family has been on this tiny little street since 1933. This was a booming steeltown hamlet and then it went into decline. 

Now, the city and the neighborhood are on the upswing. I want to be a part of that change and I want my schoolhouse residency to be an anchor on this street and in this neighborhood. 

I've traveled all over the world and there is something special about Pittsburgh besides my own nostalgia or hometown pride. I want the Rowhouse Residency to be a part of the incredible ecosystem of learning institutions here in Pittsburgh. We are such an interesting city, I think, because we have this combination of a hard working blue collar mentality and a broad appreciation of the arts. I know it's because of the ecosystem of museums, libraries, universities and independent learning institutions we have in Pittsburgh. Everyone from here has been to the Carnegie Museum and a Steeler game. City of Champions in more ways than one.

Even if you know very little about comic books please consider that comics are where many kids learn to read. Comics are words and pictures. And words and pictures are the internet. So the artform of comics promotes "visual literacy". Learning comics is like learning music or learning how to communicate with more than just words. And that's the world we live in today.

Our plan for the school is to create a dojo for students much like a martial arts academy. The beginner student will learn from more experienced students. We run the school like a sports clinic. What's wrong with your swing? We can fix it. The dojo sparring sessions (so to speak) will be recorded and broadcast. We want to have a "broadcast booth" and a radio show. We can interview veterans and rookies and make room for friendly competition in order to push the boundaries of what is possible in the artform. This is not your regular comic book academy. This is a ninja academy, a samurai school, a Jedi academy. I do a really good Yoda impression.

The student can live for a day, a weekend, a week or a month at a time in the same space. That way, the student-resident can have a total immersion in the process. Most cartoonists work out of their home, so why have an expensive school building and make the student live in a crappy dorm or apartment off campus? Why not just give them a desk and their own bedroom? The residents will take classes with me in the living room of the house. And I live next door. And my mom lives up the street and makes great spaghetti sauce and lasagna. So it's a family affair. 

Then we will broadcast lessons and publish the work of residents through the local powerhouse, Copacetic Comics. Bill Boichel, the proprietor of Copacetic Comics in the Polish Hill section of Pittsburgh, is my Yoda. I want to pass on the lessons he taught me to a new generation of Jedis. 

The circle is now complete.

=================

When I was 15, I got a copy of the video documentary The Masters of Comic Book Art. I watched it everyday after school. Jean Giraud, aka Moebius, said something which impacted me greatly then and it is something I carry with me always. Moebius said,"Like any art, the possibilities of the art are big, but the possibilities of the artist are bigger or smaller. It is the artist who has the possibility to upend, to make a pressure, to be more responsible. Because to be more responsible is to be more mature, more evolved. [...] Because it's not the publisher who will push, it's not the public. It's the artist. The artist must be the warrior who fights." 



========
Please consider supporting the school. 
If you need to know more about me and what I do, please check out these links and then come back here and consider making a pledge:
Carnegie Museum of Art profile
Tell Me Something I Don't Know podcast interview
LA Review of Books on my book Pompeii
==========
Where's the money going? We need the price of the house and the money it will take to get up to code and pass inspection. Here's the breakdown:
$12,000 cost of the house plus closing costs and taxes
$2,500 for a new roof
$2,000 for a new furnace
$2,000 for new wiring
$2,000 for new plumbing
$2,000 for new windows
$1,500 for a stove and fridge
$1,000 for sanding and finishing the floors
$1,000 for beds
$1,000 for desks
$2,000 for a risograph printer to make comic books
-----------------------
Total $29,0000 USD
-----------------------

We've reached 100% of our goal with two weeks left to go.With this achieved the school is going to be a reality.  Students will be able to be residents in just a few months. I am incredibly humbled. 

With the two remaining weeks that we have this Indiegogo going, I'd like to see if we can raise the funds for things that only felt like pipe dreams at the start of our campaign like recording equipment, schoolhouse technology and even a scholarship endowment.  I'm so excited to see what we can accomplish in the time remaining.

Let's make the Comics Workbook Rowhouse Residency the greatest learning institution it can be.

Please see newly added stretch goals at top of post under "Breaking News"


And now here's something we hope you'll really like:
Frank Santoro doing his best Columbo imitation to tell you all about the plan to build the Comics Workbook Rowhouse Residency in Pittsburgh,PA (read to yourself in your best Columbo voice)

Howzitgoin? Good, good. Me? Good, thanks. I gotta tell ya though I’m sorry to bother you again, but y’see somethin’s been troubling me and I can’t stop thinking about it. Kept me up all night. and the dog too cuz he thought I was getting up to take him to Cincinnati. What’s that? Oh. Sorry. Cincinnati is what I call the park. Cuz if I say “park” or “walk” then he gets crazy. So we say Cincinnati around here. Yeah. So. Where was I? Oh yeah. This thing has been bothering me and it’s this thing about commodity form as community form. What’s that? Oh. “Commodity form as community form.” Yeah, it’s a mouthful. And sort of puzzle. What does it mean? I don’t know. Or I think I know. Either way, I keep thinking about it.

People ask me, “Frank, what’s this I hear you are buying the house next door and turning it into your schoolhouse?” I say, yeah, it’s true. The old man who owned the property passed away. Well, no one’s been living there for twenty years. He was this old guy who lived in Florida most of the year and had a bunch of properties all over the neighborhood. I’ve wanted to buy it forever but the old man wouldn’t budge so we thought maybe someday. Anyways, the day arrived and the nephew who cut the grass, y’know, to keep the place nice over the years—well, the nephew stopped by and asked me if i wanted to buy the place. That they weren’t gonna put it on the market. Was I interested, he says? Was I interested? Of course, I’m interested. I said yes, I’ll buy it.

Trouble is, you see, I don’t have the money. Yeah, I know. Foolish of me, wasn’t it? I had to say yes, though. Otherwise it’s on the market and bang it’s gone. This way I have a chance at least. 

So I’m scraping together the money as fast as possible. Boy, I’ll tell ya though, it’s humbling. Passing the hat is a humbling experience. Why should I help this fool is what most of them are thinking, I know. It’s ok, I understand. I am foolish. But foolish choices have gotten me this far---so I gotta ride out the lucky streak. If it’s a complete disaster and I can’t get the house, well, at least I took a shot. A shot not taken is a shot missed, they say. But, it’s gotta be a good shot. You gotta take a good shot to score. 

Anyhow, can I get you a coffee or a tea? Sorry, I got alot on my mind and I gotta just talk it out, if you don’t mind. Can’t sleep. Cream and sugar? No, ok. Here ya go. You’re welcome. Let me get one, myself. Hold on.

There we are. Ok. So, about the house. We're gonna do an IndieGoGo campaign. Yeah, "crowdfunding". Yeah, I know. It's an interesting idea which we think we have to try. I mean, we gotta take the shot, right? Take it to the hoop.

What’s that? Oh. Sorry, when I say “we” I mean we, like, the school. I’m gonna make it a school next door. I like having the correspondence course for comics but I think it’s time to try to do more. I’ve been trying to figure out for years how I can expand my school—start having my students teach in some way—but I can never figure it out because the correspondence part of it is so personal. Teaching in a classroom is different. But how do you get a classroom? Do I have to join my school to another school to get their classroom? But most comics are done alone by the person making them in a room. Classrooms are good for teaching some artforms but not so great for teaching others, y’know what I mean? Like how do you teach writing in a classroom? Go around peering over the shoulders to read what they are doing? No, it’s gotta be something different. Like a residency. Like the student can live in the classroom. Work in the classroom of course, but also, sleep in the classroom and eat there too. 

Most cartoonists I know work out of their homes. So maybe if I can have a house that is a residency where the student can have classes everyday and then do the hard work in private in the same space—that might just work. Especially if the teacher lives on the same street and his mother makes really awesome spaghetti sauce and the student doesn’t have to worry about what to make for dinner. An airbnb with comic book lessons. Something like that.

The students I have already are pretty psyched about it. Many of them live in far flung backwater comics towns and here in Pittsburgh, well, we are a prime time comics town. Always have been, but things are really hoppin’ here now. So I dunno. I think it could work, cuz the students I already have would be the first wave of residents. We already know each other even if we never met in person. And then they can come here and we can work with the game plan we already know and come up with new strategies for making forward thinking comics. Does that sound hokey? I’m sorry, forgive me, I get carried away. See, I just think that for the artform to grow there need to be different types of interdisciplinary learning institutions that are outside of the traditional academy. Like there needs to be a big ecosystem. 

People say, why do we need a comics school? There aren’t many jobs in comics so why churn out these kids with no job prospects? Well, I’m not interested in that. I’m interested in churning out ninjas. I don’t see many jobs out there for ninjas. It’s understood that if you want to be a ninja you are doing it for the love of ninjadom--not for personal glory or gold. I mean, what professional ninja goes around telling people they are a ninja? I’ve never seen a “ninja needed” advertisement anywhere. 

This is why I’m intrigued by this “commodity form as community form” thing. What’s that? Oh, did I make that up? No, no, Bill Boichel came up with that one. Back in the 80s. His whole thing was that he had this comic book store in an economically depressed steel town back in the 80s. And it was the only place in the neighborhood kids could hangout without an adult. Like you see in store windows “only two kids allowed at a time” or “children must be accompanied by an adult” and all that stuff? Yeah, Bill’s store was never like that. Christ, he had couches. Kids would sit there and read. A kid who was flunking English class probably would be READING at the comic book store without a care in the world. And so, you know, Bill is a thoughtful guy and he’d start putting all this relevant material into these kids’ hands. Like he’d give a kid a Black Panther comic and tell him his theory that that “the Black Panther party” was named soon after the comic came out back in the 60s. Like he didn’t just take their quarters for beat up back issues of comics, he actually fucking cared about these kids. And that really did something to me, cuz I was one of those kids too. There was NO WAY OUT of my post-idustrial wasteland existence, really. Except there was—thru comics. Bill preached the gospel of comics and I signed up for the choir. 

He taught me about “commodity form as community form”. Meaning that what we buy and sell creates a community. And how do you engage your community in which you are buying and selling? And what are you buying? And what are you selling? 

Bill would make his own comics in the basement of the store and then print them on the xerox machine down there and then go upstairs and put it on the rack for sale. He rearranged my thinking of how a maker of art can get their work into the world. Bill was publishing comics made by the kids who hung out at the store. He had us selling our comics at our high schools. He “published” our work for us and taught us how to make money from our art. They weren’t teaching me that in high school art class. He taught us how to fish essentially. The guy changed my life.

So I want to do the same thing in my own way. I know how hard it is to gain an education in comics. How to learn the craft and how to survive in this godforsaken industry and on the circuit of church basement shows? I can help you. Really. We can help you. I have over 150 students now and I want to bring each student, if they are willing, thru the residency schoolhouse and help them level up so that they can go back into their community and pass on what Bill passed on to me. What Bill passed on to me is really something I can’t even explain except that it is part of the necessary oral tradition of art. Especially comics. Comics is such an insanely difficult thing to study because so much of the art is obscured by the marketplace. How do you balance the two when the form itself is, as they say, the bastard child of art and commerce? I know: you provide a space where the student can LIVE AND WORK. Where there is no separation between art and life or between your school’s awesome classroom and your hovel on the otherside of town. A place where the student can have a total immersion in the private process of making comics while still being tethered to a strong community. 

What’s in it for you, you ask? Well, that’s a good question. Maybe if you are, simply, a comics fan--- then someday in the future you can read the work by some of the school’s students and you’ll enjoy it. That’s probably all that is in it for you. But if you are a comics snob who is also interested in seeing the form grow then maybe you will consider supporting the school because you know that I am one passionate motherfeyer about comics and I really, really want to push the form itself to grow and to absorb new voices and disciplines to create a Jeet Kune Do-type comics style. A style, an approach to comics making that is firmly rooted in the 21st century. What does it mean it be a comics maker in the 21st century? How does a comics maker navigate the marketplace or navigate a marketplace that doesn’t exist for them? Making comics on the xerox machine and selling them by hand is still the business model. So something has got to give. Help me help my students figure this out so that the next generation won’t have such a hard time of it. That’s what you’ll get out of supporting the school: knowing that you made a difference, potentially, in the direction of the form itself.

More coffee?

So, yeah. I’m selling my collection through a private auction and now this: we’re going to do an IndieGoGo crowdfund to raise money to buy the house and start working on it. The house needs alot of work to get it up to code for inspections. But first we gotta raise the money for the down payment. If you feel like helping out you can buy something or donate here. If you want to check out the private auction then send me an email: santoroschoolATgmail. Everyone is asking why I’m doing a private auction. It’s because some of the famous artists giving me artwork to sell don’t really want to be part of a crowdfund and all that. Plus it is a way of avoiding eBay fees and that kind of thing. It is also a way of keeping the books and art in my collection IN the community because in theory the people buying stuff are comics snobs (haha, that’s a term of respect). So, for me, this plays into the "community form as commodity form thing”. Like I’m selling the collection I amassed for years—a collection that was made thru purchases made within the community—to buy a house to teach comics. So hopefully if you, the comics fan, buy something from the auction then I am selling my commodities to buy a meeting place for the community. See, how pretty that is? It’s like a circle. The end is in the beginning. I want some kid to sit on the couch at our school and read comics and maaaaybe take a workshop and get interested in comics as A WAY OUT in a spiritual sense and possibly in a financial sense. Like it’s a trade. A 21st century skillset. How to arrange words and images. Visual literacy. I mean, that’s the internet, right? Commodity form as community form. Community form as commodity form.

Take awhile, think about it. I’ll be here if you wanna stop by later. 


================

Campaign video credits:

Video by Michael Pisano | michaelpisano.com
Soundtrack by DJ Thermos | facebook.com/DjThermos

The students I have already are pretty psyched about it. Many of them live in far flung backwater comics towns and here in Pittsburgh, well, we are a prime time comics town. Always have been, but things are really hoppin’ here now. So I dunno. I think it could work, cuz the students I already have would be the first wave of residents. We already know each other even if we never met in person. And then they can come here and we can work with the game plan we already know and come up with new strategies for making forward thinking comics. Does that sound hokey? I’m sorry, forgive me, I get carried away. See, I just think that for the artform to grow there need to be different types of interdisciplinary learning institutions that are outside of the traditional academy. Like there needs to be a big ecosystem. 
People say, why do we need a comics school? There aren’t many jobs in comics so why churn out these kids with no job prospects? Well, I’m not interested in that. I’m interested in churning out ninjas. I don’t see many jobs out there for ninjas. It’s understood that if you want to be a ninja you are doing it for the love of ninjadom--not for personal glory or gold. I mean, what professional ninja goes around telling people they are a ninja? I’ve never seen a “ninja needed” advertisement anywhere. 
This is why I’m intrigued by this “commodity form as community form” thing. What’s that? Oh, did I make that up? No, no, Bill Boichel came up with that one. Back in the 80s. His whole thing was that he had this comic book store in an economically depressed steel town back in the 80s. And it was the only place in the neighborhood kids could hangout without an adult. Like you see in store windows “only two kids allowed at a time” or “children must be accompanied by an adult” and all that stuff? Yeah, Bill’s store was never like that. Christ, he had couches. Kids would sit there and read. A kid who was flunking English class probably would be READING at the comic book store without a care in the world. And so, you know, Bill is a thoughtful guy and he’d start putting all this relevant material into these kids’ hands. Like he’d give a kid a Black Panther comic and tell him his theory that that “the Black Panther party” was named soon after the comic came out back in the 60s. Like he didn’t just take their quarters for beat up back issues of comics, he actually fucking cared about these kids. And that really did something to me, cuz I was one of those kids too. There was NO WAY OUT of my post-idustrial wasteland existence, really. Except there was—thru comics. Bill preached the gospel of comics and I signed up for the choir. 
He taught me about “commodity form as community form”. Meaning that what we buy and sell creates a community. And how do you engage your community in which you are buying and selling? And what are you buying? And what are you selling? 
Bill would make his own comics in the basement of the store and then print them on the xerox machine down there and then go upstairs and put it on the rack for sale. He rearranged my thinking of how a maker of art can get their work into the world. Bill was publishing comics made by the kids who hung out at the store. He had us selling our comics at our high schools. He “published” our work for us and taught us how to make money from our art. They weren’t teaching me that in high school art class. He taught us how to fish essentially. The guy changed my life.
So I want to do the same thing in my own way. I know how hard it is to gain an education in comics. How to learn the craft and how to survive in this godforsaken industry and on the circuit of church basement shows? I can help you. Really. We can help you. I have over 150 students now and I want to bring each student, if they are willing, thru the residency schoolhouse and help them level up so that they can go back into their community and pass on what Bill passed on to me. What Bill passed on to me is really something I can’t even explain except that it is part of the necessary oral tradition of art. Especially comics. Comics is such an insanely difficult thing to study because so much of the art is obscured by the marketplace. How do you balance the two when the form itself is, as they say, the bastard child of art and commerce? I know: you provide a space where the student can LIVE AND WORK. Where there is no separation between art and life or between your school’s awesome classroom and your hovel on the otherside of town. A place where the student can have a total immersion in the private process of making comics while still being tethered to a strong community. 
What’s in it for you, you ask? Well, that’s a good question. Maybe if you are, simply, a comics fan--- then someday in the future you can read the work by some of the school’s students and you’ll enjoy it. That’s probably all that is in it for you. But if you are a comics snob who is also interested in seeing the form grow then maybe you will consider supporting the school because you know that I am one passionate motherfeyer about comics and I really, really want to push the form itself to grow and to absorb new voices and disciplines to create a Jeet Kune Do-type comics style. A style, an approach to comics making that is firmly rooted in the 21st century. What does it mean it be a comics maker in the 21st century? How does a comics maker navigate the marketplace or navigate a marketplace that doesn’t exist for them? Making comics on the xerox machine and selling them by hand is still the business model. So something has got to give. Help me help my students figure this out so that the next generation won’t have such a hard time of it. That’s what you’ll get out of supporting the school: knowing that you made a difference, potentially, in the direction of the form itself.
More coffee?
So, yeah. I’m selling my collection through a private auction and now this: we’re going to do an IndieGoGo crowdfund to raise money to buy the house and start working on it. The house needs alot of work to get it up to code for inspections. But first we gotta raise the money for the down payment. If you feel like helping out you can buy something or donate here. If you want to check out the private auction then send me an email: santoroschoolATgmail. Everyone is asking why I’m doing a private auction. It’s because some of the famous artists giving me artwork to sell don’t really want to be part of a crowdfund and all that. Plus it is a way of avoiding eBay fees and that kind of thing. It is also a way of keeping the books and art in my collection IN the community because in theory the people buying stuff are comics snobs (haha, that’s a term of respect). So, for me, this plays into the "community form as commodity form thing”. Like I’m selling the collection I amassed for years—a collection that was made thru purchases made within the community—to buy a house to teach comics. So hopefully if you, the comics fan, buy something from the auction then I am selling my commodities to buy a meeting place for the community. See, how pretty that is? It’s like a circle. The end is in the beginning. I want some kid to sit on the couch at our school and read comics and maaaaybe take a workshop and get interested in comics as A WAY OUT in a spiritual sense and possibly in a financial sense. Like it’s a trade. A 21st century skillset. How to arrange words and images. Visual literacy. I mean, that’s the internet, right? Commodity form as community form. Community form as commodity form.
Take awhile, think about it. I’ll be here if you wanna stop by later. 

================
Campaign video credits:
Video by Michael Pisano | michaelpisano.comSoundtrack by DJ Thermos | facebook.com/DjThermos

story:
Help Raise $1,750 for North Tahoe High School Jazz Band Activities

The North Tahoe High School (NTHS) Jazz Band, led by Mr. Dean Nordby, is a crucial element in our school, our community, and our student's lives.  The program is a jewel in our small school, attracting a bright, dedicated and musically talented student group that takes the music outside the school to community events, elementary schools, senior centers and disability groups.  To keep the program successful, I am willing to unicycle 35 miles -- up to the Sierra Crest at Donner Summit -- in exchange for your donation.

Mr. Nordby knows how to stretch his funds really far, whether for travel, instrument repair or music. I trust his judgement 100% and would like to continue to enable him to run his program with a little less worry about fundraising. Considering he plans and runs so many events, we could save him time thinking about finances and hopefully make his year even better. 

This campaign is important to me not only because I have a son in the program, but because your contribution will give the opportunity for over a thousand people of all ages and backgrounds to listen, watch, and be inspired by this band. In fact, watching the NTHS Jazz Band is what inspired me [who can barely keep rhythm and certainly can't dance] to start playing clarinet three years ago. 

What's in it for you? Contributors are paying it forward. The experiences given to the students and audience will be remembered so much more than a cup of coffee (or a hundred of them, if you are so generous!). 

If you don't know me, I'm an active community member and supporter of all kinds of activities at NTHS. Last year I received the Principal's Outstanding Community Member award, a humbling recognition for my volunteer work in the Engineering Technology class. And if you can fund this campaign to $1,750, I'll match your effort by riding my unicycle 35 miles on the Sierra Century on September 12th, 2015. 

I'll post updates to this campaign here and on my Facebook page. 

Can we please have your support?

Sincerely,


Ken Gracey

I'll Match Your Donation by Riding the Sierra Century - On a Unicycle! 

On August 12th is the big fundraiser for North Tahoe Middle School and High School music programs, the Tahoe Sierra Century. This fundraiser is for all music activities at these two schools, but I'd like to target these funds specifically for the NTHS Jazz Band.

Most participants ride the Sierra Century on a bicycle, but last year I tried it on a unicycle. I rode so hard that my cranks fell off. There's a big climb, too, and no brakes on a unicycle (ever ride a fixie?). Between several roadside repairs and a sag wagon I was able to finish the 30-miler but I could've done better with preparation. Here's a picture near Donner Summit.

This year, if you fund this campaign beyond the $1,750 goal, I'll step up my efforts! I'll make a 150% effort with solid gear and ride the 30-miler not only from Olympic Valley to Donner Lake and back, but I'll also swap out the 36-inch wheel unicycle for my 20-inch wheel six-foot tall unicycle and ride up and down Donner Summit on Highway 40 with the 60 and 100-mile bicycle riders (it's easier to climb with a small wheel). This climb adds five miles and 1,100 feet of elevation, and on a 20-inch wheel that's another 5,000 crank revolutions on the pedals! That's  at total of 35 miles on a unicycle - with a massive climb in the middle! I assure you it'll be tough and that I'll loose some skin on this one if I make it. . .

Mr. Dean Nordby - A Positive Influence on Band Students and Community

Mr. Nordby has a unique gift that enables him to connect with his students, guiding them to be considerate, well-rounded young men and women. His positive influence is just as important than the musical skills he develops among the students. He runs the kind of class that's open all day, with lunch time being a gathering for anybody. Here's a picture of him with his wife Beth, another great teacher. 

Students Give Back

Each year, Mr. Nordby's Jazz Band band plays at a variety of venues throughout the community and the state, with the most demanding schedule being the Jazz Tour. On this tour last year, they played for convalescent homes, elementary schools and the Braille Institute. The Jazz Band students share their music - engaging elementary school students by making them part of the band and sometimes playing the same songs four times in a day as the audience changes. 

Take a look at how they engage the students by making them part of the percussion. See that kid who's smiling? This kind of interaction creates an impressionable memory that these students will remember forever, probably even creating their own interest in music. 

After a visit to the Orange County Regional Center of the Braille Institute, the Programs Coordinator wrote a thank you note that praised the NTHS Jazz Band students for their maturity, interactivity, and the excitement the braille students showed when they played percussion. He summarized it as "we were very impressed not only at the talent and quality of performance, but also at the maturity and character of your students. I gave them a short demonstration on sighted guide and reading/writing Braille and they were the most respectful and engaged group of high schoolers I have ever presented to. After the performance we all played a quick game together and your kids were great interacting with our kids." The Jazz Band students aren't programed to act this way, they have a professional role model to follow!  

Perhaps the most impressionable visits to see are at nursing centers (convalescent homes, skilled nursing facilities). The residents really engage in the music, smiling and moving around. After the performance, the Jazz Band students talk with the residents of the home. If you've been to these places you know that every resident wants to talk. What would you think of the opportunity to see and hear jazz music from high school students as a future resident of a nursing center? If I were here it would certainly be the highlight of my week. This kind of care is part of our responsibility. 

Students Succeed as Musicians and Win University Scholarships Too

A short sampling of some of some of the Mr. Nordby-lead accomplishments include a superior rating at the Region V Band Festival (3/19/15) and an excellent rating at the Santa Cruz Jazz Festival (3/21/15).  Many individual band students have successfully auditioned for prestigious regional and state honor bands.  Seven band students from North Tahoe High made the Capitol Honor Band (Sacramento region, 1/8/15 to 1/10/15) and seven students made the NorCal Honor Band (Northern California region, 2/5/15 to 2/7/15).  In addition, two students made the All-State Honor Band (entire state of California), which is one of the top honor bands in the country.  The graduating class of 2015 had several music scholarships, too. This is a direct result of Mr. Nordby’s dedication to encouraging and enabling his students to spend time outside of the classroom to become better musicians.  Given the small size of our high school relative to the other schools also feeding into these honor bands, this is an impressive feat that speaks volumes to the quality of music instruction at North Tahoe High School.  As a side note, Mr. Nordby also currently serves as President of the Northern California Band & Choir Director’s Association.

Mr. Nordby treats music education as the gateway to life’s many opportunities to learn, and he provides wonderful music and life experiences for his students that make them better human beings.  

$1,750 for North Tahoe Jazz Band Creates 

Sure, it's an impressive amount for a high school jazz band. This money provides instruments, music and travel expenses for part of their activities - so they can share it right back. The use of the money would be at the sole discretion of Mr. Nordby, a trusted community member and teacher.  

There are no physical awards or perks for contributing to this campaign, as the cost of them would be subtracted by the total funds raised. The rewards are much more than a t-shirt or recording of music, and include:

  • Performances where the student's time and music is shared with elementary kids, elderly, and groups of all ages;  
  • Entertainment at community events;
  • Developing musicians who earn scholarships and play for their life; and  
  • Perhaps most importantly, discretionary financial support for students who need assistance to participate. 
And if the $1,750 goal is reached, I'll ride the Sierra Century 30-miler plus Donner Summit on my unicycle. If the $1,750 goal is not reached, whatever funds collected go to North Tahoe High School Jazz Band and I am not obligated to riding this part of the century on my unicycle (but I'll try to do it anyway). Don't you want to see if I can do it? 

The Impact of Your Donation

Unless you're local to North Tahoe, you may not directly benefit but please consider the following.

  • Many others will have a really positive experience like I described above.
  • Imagine yourself being a kid who got to play percussion with a band, or as an elderly person who got the treat of this band on a  Friday afternoon.
  • I'm going into this campaign to win, and I'm matching it with my own physical effort which I'll document for you after the September 12th Sierra Century.
  • We're rewarding an educator. They're unnecessarily humble yet so professional, they give 150% of their time to students, and they may spend more time with our children than we do on our own. 
We've got a combination that warrants the reward of a successful campaign.

Risks & Challenges

Here's what could happen that might affect the success of the campaign. In both events, your funds still go to NTHS Jazz Band.

  • Weather or force majeure could cause the Tahoe Sierra Century to be cancelled. September is a fairly safe time weather-wise in Lake Tahoe.   
  • I'm unable to do the Sierra Century on my unicycle due to lack of preparation, equipment failure or sudden illness. Help me fund this now so I have more inspiration to train for the ride!  

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, you can still help a whole bunch!

  • Circulate this link among your friends and networks on social media.
  • Volunteer at the Tahoe Sierra Century.

story:
Formal education can be a isolating experience..

for the deaf children in Bulgaria.


 

She's stuyding in a public school and is 7th grade. She doesn't have the chance to connect with other deaf people. She has a great desire to grow as an individual and has the potential to be one of the next leaders of the Deaf community.

He has similar issues like Gabby. But that doesn't stop him to dream of one day being a Deaf lecturer and a Sign Language Expert.



I've been lucky enough to work and volunteer for  Deaf Youth over 5 years in local Bulgarian organisations, such as the Union of the Deaf and Listen Up. I can say that these children have the potential to change the general perception of Deaf people in Bulgaria if they are given a chance. But in order to do that we need partners and experience.

Deaf do not have the same privileges as their hearing peers and we need to put a stop to it.

This is why we were invited to a 1-week camp/seminar in Australia which would give us the opportunity to exchange experience with other deaf people from different countries - the WFDY Junior camp.


The goals are of the camp are to enhancing communication skills, building self-confidence, how to be a good leader, learning new language: English and International Sign Language.

WFD (World Federation of the Deaf, a non for profit organization has been advocating for the rights of Deaf individuals including children since 1951.

WFDYS Junior camp’s theme focuses on on Courage, Knowledge, Passion and Belonging.
WFDYS have been hosting junior educational week worldwide and this year is the 6th time, taking place in Australia. More than 50 countries are participating. This year’s theme is “With Sign Language, I am Equal”.

 Your contribution will enable Deaf youths in becoming our future leaders.

1. Flight to Australia cost about $1,500 per person.

For three, it would be $4,500.

Visa for three requires $300 and entrance fee, which includes accommodation, meals and registrations cost 290-euro

Our participation in this camp would give us the inspiration and necessary skills to organize local workshops and seminars with over 100 young Deaf people.

story:
Who We Are

Our Mission:  Retribe supports youth to become powerful, self-realized adults who, together, will foster a “New Culture” built on radical acceptance and connection to self, others, and the earth.

Through our 1-2 week overnight retreats we help teens to: 

  • find purpose and direction 
  • feel a sense of acceptance and belonging in our community 
  • build connection with the earth
  • heal emotionally 
Teen challenges that we have addressed and helped teens work through at past ReTribe events include: 

  • Obsessive Compulsive Disorder 
  • suicidal thoughts and cutting 
  • social phobia 
  • habitual lying 
  • bullying others 
  • grudges towards their family 
  • grieving losses 
  • Post Traumatic Stress Disorder 
Through all this healing we also provide a space of joyful celebration of life. It is so rewarding to help teens release what is holding them back and see their light and joy begin to shine through. We sing, dance, swim, play games, laugh and enjoy our time together in the beautiful rolling hills and woods of Vermont!

Kim Coe, Director of Residential and Community Treatment Services at Lund (a family support agency) for over twenty years, shared the following words with us about her take on ReTribe's work: 

"At ReTribe, a space is created that allows the participants to re-balance and center themselves.  It is an environment that invites healing and growth by providing unconditional acceptance and compassion.  Children learn to play and to be inspired by their natural environment in a manner that our culture has made less accessible in the day to day...It is my hope that someday all children will have an opportunity like this because I know that it will change the future for all in a very positive way."

Our Success Lies in our Unique Skillsets and Experience

We are a small community of teachers, outdoor educators, psychotherapists, and artists in Vermont who strive to bring cultural change and healing to children, teens, and adults. We use a variety of techniques, including mindfulness meditation, breathwork, wilderness solo, small group sharing, improvisational theater, and live action adventure games, to create powerful healing as well as wildly fun programming.

For a better understanding of what we do, please watch this beautiful video explaining our work!


The Need for a Scholarship Fund 

We have never turned a teen away for lack of funds and have managed to provide some form of scholarship to dozens of teens. Last summer, 25% of the teens at ReTribe received partial or full scholarships! Without outside funding for a scholarship fund we are unable to do this in a way that is financially sustainable for our organization.  Each year our retreats have grown, allowing us to have a positive impact on more and more youth and their families!

Will you donate to help us continue make our healing retreats available to teens from low-income families?

We highly value bringing teens together from varied socioeconomic backgrounds and helping them to learn from one another. As we go into our 5th summer we are asking for your help to be able to provide our programs to more teens in need. With this scholarship fund, we will be able to offer scholarships to more teens and pay our staff an adequate stipend while building financial stability. 

In addition to other fundraising efforts such as applying for grants and building major donor relationships, raising $3,500 in this annual fundraiser is an important source of funding for our small organization. 

Whatever amount you can give will help and remember to check out the great perks you can get with your donation!

Your Impact

                  

The challenges that teens face today are widespread and serious.  According to the National Institutes of Health, approximately 46.3% of youth (aged 13 - 18) will have a mental health disorder. A recent study found that 8.5% of American youth (aged 8 -18) show signs of addictive behavior in video game playing (Iowa State University and the National Institute on Media and the Family). Moreover, 1 in 11 American high school students attempts suicide. Suicide is the third leading cause of death in youth (aged 10 - 24) (CDC). ReTribe addresses these mental health issues at their core and your contributions will allow us to reach more people in need and have a bigger impact on the world.

Here is one parents story about the deep impact this experience had on their son and their family:

"Immediately after I picked up Jake from ReTribe, some really beautiful and transformative communication began. He was excited to share his experience with us; a light I had not seen in many years emanated from within him--the  Jake I really needed to see again. Stopping for dinner on our way home, I listened as he talked about the week--his interpersonal skills were suddenly astounding. At one point, he stopped mid-sentence and began to tell me about how he remembered something while at ReTribe that he had forgotten over the previous years. He said "I remembered how much I love you, Mom, I really missed you and wanted to tell you but had no way to get in touch with you--so I wrote to you in my journal". Now, I can't even begin to explain how much I needed to hear that from him, and I can tell you that even as I recall this moment now it brings tears to my eyes. As I sat there at the table crying onto my dinner plate, Jake proceeded to talk about his brother - how close they used to be, how he didn't know what happened, but he wanted to be close to him again. It was really surreal for me. And it didn't stop there. I thought when we got home that this confident loving Jake might quickly disappear. I waited for the ball to drop, it seemed just too good to be true; but it didn't and it has been 5 months."

Hear from the teens in their own words about how ReTribe has impacted them in this video:



Spread The Love

                                              

Whether or not you are able to make a financial contribution, please help spread the word about our campaign to others you know that may want to donate. You can use the Indiegogo share tools. Also be sure to like us on Facebook!

Additionally, being a new organization, we could use your help to spread the word about our programming to any teens you know that may be interested in attending our retreats. Please help us connect to teens who could benefit from this experience, regardless of their economic needs. 

Please visit our website www.ReTribe.org to see our summer 2016 retreat dates and registration information.

Thank you so much for your help.

In community,

The ReTribe Staff
story_txt:
Who We Are
Our Mission:  Retribe supports youth to become powerful, self-realized adults who, together, will foster a “New Culture” built on radical acceptance and connection to self, others, and the earth.
Through our 1-2 week overnight retreats we help teens to: 



find purpose and direction 

feel a sense of acceptance and belonging in our community 
build connection with the earth
heal emotionally 

Teen challenges that we have addressed and helped teens work through at past ReTribe events include: 


Obsessive Compulsive Disorder 
suicidal thoughts and cutting 
social phobia 
habitual lying 
bullying others 
grudges towards their family 
grieving losses 
Post Traumatic Stress Disorder 
Through all this healing we also provide a space of joyful celebration of life. It is so rewarding to help teens release what is holding them back and see their light and joy begin to shine through. We sing, dance, swim, play games, laugh and enjoy our time together in the beautiful rolling hills and woods of Vermont!

Thank you so much for your help.
In community,

story:
About Us

SEEDS Community Resolution Center is a community-based nonprofit that offers conflict resolution programs and services to schools, residents, businesses, and communities in Northern California. 

The SEEDS Restorative Justice team is a small but passionate crew. We are committed to positively impacting school culture, creating spaces that repair harm, and restoring relationships affected by conflict. We're currently serving over 20 schools in Hayward, Berkeley, Pittsburg, and Napa. 

As a fairly new team, we are excited about attending the upcoming National Association of Community and Restorative Justice bi-annual conference, 
"The Future of Restorative Community Justice: Building Sustainable Communities." Many of our sister organizations will be present for this important conference and we want to represent SEEDS and our good work at this national gathering of RJ practitioners. But we can't get there without your help!


What We Need 

This year's NACRJ conference will be held in Fort Lauderdale, FL. By attending, we will receive intensive training by a renowned RJ practitioner based in Brazil, learn from speakers like Cornel West and Sujatha Baliga, and network with other RJ leaders in the field, both nationally and internationally. 

While we have enough funds to cover part of our team's registration fees and travel costs, we don't have enough for two additional team members to join us. We'll need $2,800 to cover the remaining amount. Your support will enable us to pay for our flights from California to Florida, and to cover our housing/accommodation costs.

Would you consider partnering with us to help meet our $2,800 goal by May 15th? By investing in our trip to the NACRJ conference, you will be sowing seeds of peacemaking work in the Bay Area and contributing to the broader restorative justice movement in schools. 

Every dollar counts! Additionally, because your donations will be going to SEEDS, your support is tax deductible. 


Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren't able to contribute financially, please help spread the word through email, Facebook, and Twitter and encourage others to support our campaign!

story:
Ryan Millet took an important stand and became an "Upstander" rather than a bystander.

Ryan is the fourth year Dentistry student who was the whistleblower for the Dalhousie Dentistry "Gentlemen's" Facebook group.  He and his family with three young children  (pictured above) suffered punitive measures as a result of his bringing the misogynist Facebook page to light.

Although I have not met nor talked to Ryan,  I felt compelled, as a Dalhousie faculty member, to offer my support for the impressive way he has handled this difficult situation.  I hope you will also offer support and thanks to Ryan and his family through this campaign, your donations, and  by your comments.

Ryan is an international student so  has substantial educational debts. While  his legal team did much of their work pro bono  there are still significant legal expenses. 

Let's help Ryan see that Canadians, Nova Scotians, members of the Dalhousie community far and wide, as well as others, applaud his tenacity and ethical stance.

Please get the word out through all of your networks. 

For those of you who would rather donate directly to a bank account, TD Canada Trust will accept donations at their branches. The deposits go to the "Lesley Barnes in trust for Ryan Millet" account  Quinpool Road, Halifax, Nova Scotia.

Lesley Barnes

story:
East Side Community High School is dedicated to experiential learning. Week Without Walls is a chance for every student in the school to explore a topic of interest to him/her outside of the school building. 11 young women have chosen to take part in "The Importance of Sisterhood." This four day trip to Cape May, New Jersey has the ultimate goal of taking these city girls out of NYC and exposing them to things outside of their comfort zone in an effort to help them grasp the importance of sisterhood and teamwork. 9th and 10th grade girls will be paired with dynamic 11th graders who will mentor them and bond with them in an effort to promote this idea that women are so much stronger together.

What We Need & What You Get

  • To rent a van, feed the girls and get them exploring (canoeing, whale watching, historical and ecological tours), we need roughly $2,000.
  • When you contribute to this campaign, you will receive a personal letter from one of the participants detailing what she experienced and learned.
  • If we don't meet our goal, the trip will still happen, but the girls will be asked to contribute. Our students and their parents may not have $150 to contribute to this experience. We really need your help!

The Impact

  • When you donate to this campaign you are sending the message that you believe in women's empowerment. A lot of young girls today don't quite understand or appreciate the hurdles that women have had to jump over in order to make progress in a male dominated society. They often compete against each other in negative ways and tear each other down. This needs to stop and this trip will contain a lot of opportunities for the girls to build trust in each other and to recognize how much stronger they are together.
  • I worked at an all girl's school in Liberia last year, and the absence of sisterhood was a big struggle there as well. The girls often competed for attention and hurt each other in the process. As the school's principal, I created a Sisterhood campaign to help the girls learn to love and respect each other. While it didn't fix all the problems, it forced the girls to reflect on their actions and to actively try to change.

Risks & Challenges

  • I know that a cool trip to Cape May doesn't sound like much of "cause." However, most of these girls have never left NYC and many of them are in dire need of a "sister" mentor to support them as they navigate the obstacles that high school and life are throwing their way. 
  • Please, please, please don't overlook the importance of Sisterhood when deciding whether or not to contribute.

story:
Med Film Factory is an advanced training program for teams of Arab producers and directors working on their first or second feature narrative film project.

This unique training opportunity aimed at Arab filmmakers from the MENA (Middle East / North Africa) region was created in 2010 when a concept initiated by the Royal Film Commission – Jordan in partnership with Sud Ecriture – Tunisia and the Huston School of Film & Digital Media – Ireland materialized into a fully-developed training program with the financial support of the Euromed Audiovisual program of the European Union, which funded the program between 2011 and 2014.

Med Film Factory is now suspended due to lack of funds and to the non-renewal of the Euromed Audiovisual program that funded it these past few years and we need your support to keep it going!

As of 2015, the training will take place on two interrelated workshops:

The Producers’ Workshop: For six days, producers are guided by professionals through an advanced coaching program tackling various aspects of producing: creative producing, marketing, funding, legalities and pitching, with emphasis on regional co-production, exhibition and distribution.

The Directors’ Workshop: Guided by reputable regional and international film tutors and experts, selected directors join group, one-on-one sessions and hands-on exercises throughout the eight-day specialized training program. Experts will work with directors on their scripts, directing techniques, camera, sound and editing with the aim of helping them develop their visual languages as directors. In addition, participants will have the opportunity to direct a short film from or inspired by their feature projects, supervised by tutors and experts.  Local crew and cast will work with them through all stages of production.

To replace the third training session of the previous version of the program, the Independent Film Assembly, participants will be directly dispatched by Med Film Factory to participate in film markets of international and regional festivals. 



Med Film Factory is the only Arab training program in the region that is specifically designed to develop the skills of Arab producers and Arab directors.

It seeks to enhance the participants’ creative and professional skills as well as support them in the realization of their projects. It also anticipates to contribute to the creation of collective connections within the Arab regional film industry, in particular to encourage the regional support of independent creative voices and films through all the stages of filmmaking that will help sustain the overall Mediterranean film industry.


Out of the 24 feature film projects that went through the program, two feature films have been shot and are now in post-production. Eight more are now in pre-production.

Two short films produced during the Directors’ Workshop that took place in April 2014 were selected to the official short film competition of the 25th edition of Carthage Film Festival in 2014 and are screening in various film festivals.

In addition, many participants from all three cycles have individually developed success stories in the film industry thanks to their experience in Med Film Factory.


Three cycles into the project, Med Film Factory has matured into a beautifully crafted training program which has benefited around 50 Arab producers and directors. Annually anticipated, the program is one of the most important training opportunities aimed at Arab producers and directors, its mark significant when it comes to developing the skills of filmmakers from the Arab World.

Med Film Factory helped Arab film directors to develop their professional directing skills, thus enhancing the artistic quality and value of regional film projects. It has contributed in training Arab producers in their profession and has supported them to find new methods of producing, financing, exhibition and distribution.

Also it encouraged audio-visual professionals from the Mediterranean countries to invest, support and produce film projects by Arab and independent filmmakers to present to the audiences a good range of films by regional filmmakers.

Finally, Med Film Factory helped in supporting local and regional film appreciation and its literature and contributed towards a wider range of distribution and circulation of films within the Mediterranean countries as a market for films. 


The target of this crowd-funding campaign is set at 75,500 USD. The below chart shows a budget breakdown of the raised amount: 

Since 2011, 24 teams of Arab producers and directors participated in the training sessions offered by Med Film Factory. Each team was composed of one producer and one writer/director, both attached to a feature film project with which they applied to the program. Hereafter is the complete list of participants for the three cycles that took place between 2011 and 2014:

Projects and Participants- 1st Cycle 2011-2012

  • ALGIERS BY NIGHT - writer/ director Yanis Koussim; producer Tewfik Rays- Algeria
  • COLORED FEATHERS - writer/ director Mohammad Al Hushki; producer Rula Nasser- Jordan
  • THE FLAG (previously entitled NARRATIVE) - writer/ director Firas Khoury; producer Baher Agbaria- Palestine
  • RETRIEVAL - writer/ director Dhafer El Abidine, co-director Majdi Smiri; producer Riadh Ghariani- Tunis
  • SHADOW OF A MAN- writer/ director Niam Itani- producer Lara Abu Saifan- Lebanon
  • THE BUILDING - writer/ director Suhad Khatib; producer Azza Hourani- Jordan
  • LONG LIVE SADDAM - writer/ director Katia Jarjoura; producer Monika Borgmann- Lebanon
  • TOURA FOURA - writer/ director Bahri Ben Yahmed; producer Asma Chiboub- Tunis

Projects and Participants- 2nd Cycle 2012-2013

  • A FEW DAYS IN SYRIA - writer/director Ahmad Ameen & producer Majd Hijjawi - Jordan
  • THE KIDNAP - writer/director Dima Hamdan & producer Vida Rizq - Jordan
  • 1982 - writer/director Oualid Mouness & producer Feyrouz Serhal - Lebanon
  • COLD COFFEE - writer/director Toufic Khreich & producer Lara Ayoub - Lebanon
  • TREES ALSO DIE - writer/director Rabih Al Amine & producer Ihab Al Amine - Lebanon
  • SITUATION UNDER CONTROL - writer/director Hany Fawzy & producer Eman Hameda - Egypt
  • FULL MOON NIGHT - writer/director Fares Naanaa, co-writer Nadia Khammari & producer Sarra Ben Hassen - Tunisia 
  • THE LATE LIFE - writer/director Youssef Chebbi & producer Melik Kochbati - Tunisia

Projects and Participants- 3rd Cycle 2013-2014

  • SHAKE - writer/director Deema Dabis & producer Tamador Abu Laban – Jordan/Palestine
  • KILLING ETERNITY - writer/producer Nour Halawani & co-writer/director Menna Ekram – Jordan/Egypt 
  • THE SCRIPT IS READY (previously entitled CASTING) - writers/directors Ahmad “Tarazan” Abo Nasser & Mohammad “Arab” Abo Nasser & producer Rashid Abdelhamid – Palestine 
  • TWO ROOMS AND A PARLOR - writer Mohames Salah ElAzzab, director Sherif Elbendary & producer Racha Najdi – Egypt, Lebanon 
  • THE TRANSLATOR - writer/director Rana Kazkaz & producer Anas Khalaf, co-producer Osama Bawardi – Syria/ Jordan
  • AL YASMINE - writer/director Ismahane Lahmar & producer Hanane Ben Mahmoud - Tunisia 
  • UNTIL THE END OF TIME - writer/director Yasmine Chouikh & producer Karima Chouikh – Algeria
  • HONEY CIGAR - writer/director Kamir Ainouz & producer Hassiba BelHadj – Algeria

On the other hand, Med Film Factory hosted a number of internationally acclaimed filmmakers and film professionals who mentored at its various training sessions. Hereafter is the complete list of Tutors and Experts who accompanied the participants during the Producers’ and the Directors’ Workshops:

Producers’ Coaching Programme- December 2-7th 2011- Tunis

  • Bero Beyer - Producing Tutor– The Netherlands
  • Michel Feller- Producing Tutor- Belgium
  • Pim Hermeling- Marketing and Distribution Expert- The Netherlands
  • Karine Riahi- Legal and Contracts Expert- France/ Tunisia
  • Stefano Tealdi- Expert on Pitching- Italy
  • Habib Attia - Regional Visiting Expert- Tunisia

Directors’ Workshop- January 7-14th 2012- Amman

  • Merzak Allouache- Tutor Director– Algeria
  • Charles McDougall- Tutor Director- UK
  • Jacques Fieschi- Script Editing Tutor- France
  • Rebecca O’Flanagan- Script Editing Tutor- Ireland
  • Larry Sider- Sound Design Expert- USA/ UK
  • Diane Baratier- DoP Expert- France
  • Nadia Ben Rachid- Editing Expert- Tunisia/ France

Directors’ Workshop- July 11-18th 2012- Amman

  • Ghassan Salhab - Script Editor– Lebanon
  • Jérôme Boivin - Script Editor & Tutor Director- France
  • Raja Amari - Tutor Director - Tunisia
  • Gary Sanctuary - Sound Design Expert - UK
  • Diane Baratier - DoP Expert- France
  • Pauline Dairou - Editing Expert - France

Producers’ Coaching Programme- December 2-7th 2012- Tunis

  • Michel Feller – Tutor Producer – Belgium
  • Marianne Dumoulin – Tutor Producer - France
  • Pim Hermeling - Marketing and Distribution Expert- the Netherlands
  • Lamia Slim – Negotiations & Contracts Expert- Tunisia
  • Stefano Tealdi - Expert on Pitching- Italy
  • Habib BelHadi & Habib Attia - Regional Visiting Experts- Tunisia

Producers’ Coaching Programme- January 31st –February 5th 2014- Amman

  • Michel Feller – Tutor Producer – Belgium
  • Marianne Dumoulin – Tutor Producer – France
  • Nelleke Driessen - Marketing and Distribution Expert- the Netherlands
  • Stefano Tealdi - Expert on Pitching- Italy
  • Magali Negroni - Script Editor – France 
  • Rebecca O’Flanagan - Script Editor- Ireland
  • Hager Karray - Expert on Screenplay Characters’ Psychology – Tunisia 

Directors’ Workshop- April 8th -15th 2014- Amman

  • Nadir Moknèche - Tutor Director – Algeria
  • Robert Quinn - Tutor Director – Ireland 
  • Larry Sider - Sound Design Expert - USA
  • Antoine Héberlé - DoP Expert- France
  • Isabela Araujo - Editing Expert – Brazil 

And finally, an impressive line-up of industry professionals attended Med Film Factory’s Independent Film Assemblies to meet and network with the participants around their projects to discuss various opportunities of collaboration to enable these projects to develop further:

The Independent Film Assembly 1st CycleApril 14-15th 2012 at the Dead Sea- Jordan

Selected participants were invited to meet with regional and international professional guests: Karl Baumgartner, Producer/Distributor – Pandora Film; Gianluca Chakra, Managing Partner – Front Row Filmed Entertainment; Nadine Toukan, Producer; Pim Hermeling, Owner/CEO – Wild Bunch Benelux Distribution; Lucas Rosant, Dubai Film Connection Manager - Dubai International Film Festival; Zeina Sfeir, Publicist, PR & Marketing; Iwana Chronis, Hubert Bals Fund Manager – Rotterdam International Film Festival; Michel Zana, Producer/Distributor - Sophie Dulac Productions.  In addition, two Case Studies were organized with emphasis on film distribution, marketing and exhibition regionally: Zeina Sfeir, Publicist, PR and Marketing presented the marketing campaign of Where Do We Go Now, a film by Nadine Labaki as well as its theatrical distribution plan, DVD, TV and Video on Demand; Jordanian Producer Nadine Toukan moderated the ‘Reinventing Distribution’ session, with the participation of Jordanian experts, explored the unconventional means of distribution.

For more information on Guests and teams please download the Book of Projects

The Independent Film Assembly 2nd Cycle - March 22nd-23rd 2013 in Beirut - Lebanon.

Selected participants were invited to meet with regional and international professional guests: Adrienne Frejacques, ARTE France; Nadim Cheikhrouha, Screen Runner; Pim Hermeling, Wild Bunch Benelux Distribution; Nelleke Driessen, Fortissimo Films; Roman Paul, Razor Film Produktion; Stephane Parthenay, Pyramide Productions; Rima Mismar, Arab Fund for Arts and Culture (AFAC); Pierre Sarraf, Né à Beyrouth Productions.  In addition to speed dating sessions between the participants and guests, networking sessions took place as well as a case study about the co-production and distribution of the film “Wadjda” by Haifaa Al-Mansour, presented by German co-producer Roman Paul of Razor Film Produktion.

For more information on Guests and teams please download the Book of Projects

The Independent Film Assembly 3rd Cycle - June 6th -7th 2014 at the Dead Sea- Jordan.

Selected participants were invited to meet with regional and international professional guests: Adrienne Frejacques, ARTE France; Christoph Thoke, Mogador Film; Pim Hermeling, Wild Bunch Benelux Distribution; Delphine Tomson, Les Films du Fleuve; Dominique Besnehard, Mon Voisin Productions ; Eric Lagesse, Pyramide Productions; Jessica Khoury, Metropolis Cinema; Palmyre Badinier, Les Film de Zayna.  In addition to speed dating sessions between the participants and guests, networking sessions took place. German film director Werner Herzog was the Assembly’s keynote speaker and had a session with the participants followed by a Q & A.

For more information on Guests and teams please download the Book of Projects


Med Film Factory is currently suspended due to lack of funds and to the non-renewal of the Euromed Audiovisual program that funded it these past few years.

We need your support to keep it going!

Training in film production is non-existent in the Arab World. Producers are lacking the skills and attitude to build relationships with industry actors. Med Film Factory specifically works on enhancing producing and pitching skills to enable Arab producers to perform efficiently and deliver successfully as they embark on producing their feature films.

The region is also lacking advanced training programs for Arab directors, enabling them to develop their directing skills by allowing them to shoot a segment of their feature film projects in a safe environment under the guidance of established international film directors.  

With your help, Med Film Factory will continue to train more producers and directors from the Arab World.

Help us raise the funds to organize a complete edition in 2015!
story_txt:
Med Film Factory is an advanced training
program for teams of Arab producers and directors working on their first or
second feature narrative film project. 
This unique training
opportunity aimed at Arab filmmakers from the MENA (Middle East / North Africa)
region was created in 2010 when a concept initiated by the Royal Film
Commission – Jordan in partnership with Sud Ecriture – Tunisia and the Huston
School of Film & Digital Media – Ireland materialized into a fully-developed
training program with the financial support of the Euromed Audiovisual program
of the European Union, which funded the program between 2011 and 2014. 
Med Film Factory is now suspended due to lack of funds and to the non-renewal of the Euromed Audiovisual program that funded it these past few years and we need your support to keep it going!
As
of 2015, the training will take place on two interrelated workshops: 

The
Producers’ Workshop: For six days, producers are guided
by professionals through an advanced coaching program tackling various aspects
of producing: creative producing, marketing, funding, legalities and pitching,
with emphasis on regional co-production, exhibition and distribution.

The
Directors’ Workshop: Guided by reputable regional and
international film tutors and experts, selected directors join group,
one-on-one sessions and hands-on exercises throughout the eight-day specialized
training program. Experts will work with directors on their scripts, directing
techniques, camera, sound and editing with the aim of helping them develop
their visual languages as directors. In addition, participants will have the
opportunity to direct a short film from or inspired by their feature projects,
supervised by tutors and experts.  Local crew and cast will work with them
through all stages of production.
To
replace the third training session of the previous version of the program, the Independent
Film Assembly, participants will be directly dispatched by Med Film Factory
to participate in film markets of international and regional festivals. 


 
Med Film Factory is the only Arab training program in the region
that is specifically designed to develop the skills of Arab producers and Arab
directors. 
It seeks to enhance the participants’ creative and professional
skills as well as support them in the realization of their projects. It
also anticipates to contribute to the creation of collective connections within
the Arab regional film industry, in particular to encourage the regional
support of independent creative voices and films through all the stages of
filmmaking that will help sustain the overall Mediterranean film industry.






Out of the 24 feature film projects that
went through the program, two feature films have been shot and are now in
post-production. Eight more are now in pre-production. 
Two short films produced during the
Directors’ Workshop that took place in April 2014 were selected to the official
short film competition of the 25th edition of Carthage Film Festival in 2014
and are screening in various film festivals. 
In addition, many participants from all
three cycles have individually developed success stories in the film industry
thanks to their experience in Med Film Factory.
   



Three cycles into the project, Med Film
Factory has matured into a beautifully crafted training program which has
benefited around 50 Arab producers and directors. Annually anticipated, the
program is one of the most important training opportunities aimed at Arab
producers and directors, its mark significant when it comes to developing the
skills of filmmakers from the Arab World.
Med Film Factory helped Arab film
directors to develop their professional directing skills, thus enhancing the
artistic quality and value of regional film projects. It has contributed in training
Arab producers in their profession and has supported them to find new methods
of producing, financing, exhibition and distribution.
Also it encouraged audio-visual
professionals from the Mediterranean countries to invest, support and produce
film projects by Arab and independent filmmakers to present to the audiences a
good range of films by regional filmmakers. 
Finally, Med Film Factory helped in supporting
local and regional film appreciation and its literature and contributed towards
a wider range of distribution and circulation of films within the Mediterranean
countries as a market for films. 
   



The target of this crowd-funding campaign is set at 75,500 USD. The below chart shows a budget breakdown of the raised amount: Since 2011, 24 teams of Arab producers
and directors participated in the training sessions offered by Med Film
Factory. Each team was composed of one producer and one writer/director, both
attached to a feature film project with which they applied to the program.
Hereafter is the complete list of participants for the three cycles that took
place between 2011 and 2014: 
Projects and
Participants- 1st Cycle 2011-2012

ALGIERS BY NIGHT - writer/ director Yanis Koussim; producer Tewfik
Rays- Algeria

Nasser- Jordan

Lebanon

story:
Niagara to Nelson or bust!!!

I'm a Kootenay Girl, born and raised in the mountains of BC, and I have a couple of Kootenay Kids, actually teens, but Kootenay Kids sounds better. ;0)

We ended up here in Niagara Falls by  a long, strange, adventurous string  of circumstances that at this point I'd prefer not to tell in its entirety, it's been a long strange trip, but it's time for me and my Kootenay Kids to get back to our family and our mountains, back to Nelson, BC,  and frankly, moving across the country and starting a new life  is really freakin' expensive. 

Getting home is going to be as much of an adventure as getting here was, except this time I'm doing it as a single mum, and on a tight time frame. I think this is an adventure worth sharing, it's going to be amusing, sad, exciting and stressful, I've made so many wonderful connections while here, it will be hard to leave, but the pull of my people and those big huge rocks sticking out of the ground is too great, greater than Lake Ontario....

'Survivor Ontario'

...........

'Back to the Kootenays'


..........
Although, as you can see by my perks, I plan to unload as much stuff as I can bear to part with, there's stuff that just has to get to BC, and I see no better way to get it and me back,  than on the road that got me here.  Road trip!!!! 
I'm guessing in total our relocation will set me back about $10 000, I'm hoping that by being creative, and perking out some really cool stuff that I can raise most, if not all of that here.  My goal is to be able to start my new life without going into debt, or begging (too much) from my parents. I know I've got a lot of friends and family and connetions (that's my word for internet connections) who know BC is where me and my kids belong. Join our journey home! <3
Niagara to Nelson or bust!!! Perks
Savannah Dry Garden

I've got balls

Pickle Jarden

Pitcher Garden
My green

Speed Queen

My trusty steed

Disposable Nation by Heather Fraser. 


The most important donation you can give me though is your moral support!!! Check back here from time to time, find me on Facebook and follow along on Twitter @niagaratonelson 
And thank you in advance for helping us return to our church, the mountains.
<3

story:
About Oregon Koto-Kai

Founded by Koto Master Mitsuki Dazai in 2012, Oregon Koto-Kai works to bring the ancient sound of Japanese Koto music to live audiences in the Pacific Northwest.

We have performed at the Camellia Festival in Newburg, the Oregon Shakespeare Festival in Ashland, and more. With an extensive repertoire of both traditional and contemporary music, Oregon Koto–Kai provides a powerful link to the unique sounds of ancient and modern Japan.

We are a registered 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization.

Here's a taste of what we sound like in concert.


Our Goal

The goal of our Indiegogo campaign is to bring an expert koto specialist from Japan to Oregon to professionally restring our kotos for next year's performance season.

What is koto?


The koto is a traditional Japanese instrument dating back to the ancient Nara Period some 1300 years ago.

Measuring over six feet from end to end, the koto derives its unique sound from the thirteen strings which stretch along its length. These strings, which are braced across thirteen independent, movable bridges, allows the koto to be tuned to a wide range of musical scales.

As with any stringed instrument, the strings of the koto wear out over time, and must be replaced every three years to maintain their rich tonal quality. However, unlike modern stringed instruments with tuning pegs, traditional kotos must have their strings tension fitted by professional craftsmen who have trained for years in the art of building and maintaining kotos.

Koto Specialists

For more than a thousand years, koto players have taken their instruments to specialists to have them restrung. The process of restringing is very demanding, as too little tension, or too much, can result in undesirable or unusable sounds, and may even damage the instrument.

As there are none in the Americas, koto craftsmen are typically brought from Japan to restring kotos in the States.

Project Description

The condition of our instruments greatly affects our performance. In order to continue delivering high quality koto music to the people of our community, our kotos must be professionally restrung this year.

The long nylon strings of the koto stretch and wear over time. As their elasticity wanes, so too does their rich, bright, and clear tonal quality, resulting in dull sounds and muddy music. Furthermore, the longer the strings go without being replaced, the more likely they are to break — potentially marring a live performance.

As a professional koto group, it is imperative that we keep our instruments in the best possible condition. For this reason, we will bring a master craftsman 5,000 miles from Japan to restring our kotos.

The manual labor of koto restringing is very tedious, time-consuming, and costly. At Oregon Koto-Kai, we have 29 kotos that need restringing — work which will take a professional koto craftsman no less than three days to complete.

We will each pay for strings and labor on our own kotos. This campaign is to cover the cost of transportation for the master craftsman to and from the U.S., as well as food and lodging during his stay.

Our Costs

This campaign will cover the following:
  • Travel for the master craftsman
  • Food for the master craftsman
  • Lodging for the master craftsman
  • Video production & English copywriting
  • Campaign perks & Indiegogo fees

Total: $5500

The costs of strings and labor will be paid by the members of Koto-Kai. However, to bring the master craftsman to the U.S. from Japan — we need your support!

Because restringing our kotos is of vital importance to our ensemble, all funding received will go toward restringing our kotos as listed above. As a nonprofit 501(c)(3) organization, any additional funding will go to promote the 2015-2016 Oregon Koto-Kai performance season. Thank you for your generous support!

What You Get

By contributing to our campaign, you have the opportunity to show your support for traditional Japanese culture and music, and to receive various perks as listed on this page. There's everything from mugs and t-shirts, to concert tickets, private performances, and more — so definitely check it out.

And of course thank you so much, one and all, for contributing to our cause!

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't contribute? You can still help by sharing our campaign among your friends and on your social networks. And if the sound of koto speaks to you, please let others know about this wonderful ancient instrument.

Domo Arigatou!

Thank you so much!

Sincerely,
Mitsuki Dazai and Oregon Koto-Kai

Sincerely,Mitsuki Dazai and Oregon Koto-Kai

story: I want to take a week off and travel for my birthday. I will start in Atlanta BUT I want everyone that contributes to my birthday fund to name an interesting place in america that I should see, be it a small town roadside attraction or a big city escapade. the more you contribute the more say so in what I have to do, the sky the limit, as long as its safe. At the end of the fund raising I will set off in my Toyota Yaris and hit as many of the places and do everything you suggest as fast as humanly possible
